column10: Honestly my favorite game of all time. Been playing since Risk of Rain was the only game and I can't wait to see the universe grow.

Before buying do yourself a favor, go look at competing games in the genres playercount and look at this games player count, Risk of Rain 2 gets several thousand players concurrently at any given time and released 4 years ago, TBOI Repentance release 2 years ago and has 20k players concurrently at any given time.

This game has less than 500 concurrent players at any given time.  BECAUSE IT SUCKS. Hoppoo unfortunately took ROR1 upgraded the graphics and then made every mechanic that made ROR1 good, worse.  Maps are bigger for no reason with no more stuff do in them to compensate. The enemy scaling is less forgiving. Providence trials are just bad in every way. Last but not least even the new stuff they added from ROR2 is bad. Artificer is terrible and easily in the running for worst character. The new enemies they added are bad.  Also don't forget to google to see if they changed any of the bosses, so you can find out they didn't so all the terrible bosses that literally just sit still while you kill them, Ifrit Cremator, Pigs, they all still suck and literally get defeated by spawning near a ledge, or become invincible if they spawn in a bad spot. None of these things will be changed, they have been mentioned since release and no upcoming changes have been announced.

Game is very disappointing, you could legitimately throw a dart at a board with images of the last 100 rogue lites released attached to it and hit a better game. This game is nothing special and a modded ROR1 experience is better than anything you would get from this game.

7/10

Risk of Rain was an ok game, I never really cared for it but I got all achievements

Risk of Rain 2 is an AMAZING game that is super fun, I had a blast getting all achievements

But Risk of Rain Returns... Oh BOY is this game a piece of work. If spending an hour on a good run and dying to enemies you literally cannot avoid because you're restricted to one axis sounds fun, than you'd like this game.
The difficulty of this game feels absurd and downright unfun at times and the providence trials are a PAIN to even play. (I've given them ~30-40 attempts and no wins. You have to beat them FIFTEEN TIMES to get an achievement.)

I will admit you can lower the difficulty a ton and cheese a lot of the game. However the base, unchanged game is too difficult for my tastes and some achievements are so mind-numbingly terribly designed that I just can't recommend this game to anyone who is a casual or likes 100%ing games.
I like earning achievements in games, even really grindy ones (looking at you, Blades of the Darkmoon from Dark Souls 3), but the RNG reliance and brutal design of this game has left me completely uninterested in putting any more time into it.

My rant is over, I just needed to put this out.
I know roguelites at their core are RNG-based and require good runs, but this one just feels way overtuned.
At least it isn't as bad as the Peglin cruciball...

For a fistful of dollars, you can have the original Risk of Rain; a classic but clunky forerunner of the roguelike genre.

For a few dollars more, you can have Risk of Rain Returns; a faithful & polished remaster of the original.

The good: the original soundtrack still bangs. Remastered sprites are beautiful. Gameplay is fluid. New items & survivors are ace.

The bad: only a few survivors a rewarded for beating the game, so there's little to strive for. Most items are locked behind gimmicky challenges instead. Almost all meaningful unlocks can be cheesed by altering player damage & defence. Adjustable difficulty sliders trivialise the game. It's a weird design choice imo.

The ugly: Providence trials are hit or miss. Some are interesting gimmicks, many are frustrating and irrelevant to the core gameplay loop. The final Providence trial is tried to 15 Steam achievements. To 100% this game, you have to beat the same trial 15 times, and it's identical every time (i.e. same items, same levels, same monsters). It takes 20 - 30 minutes per attempt, and most failures occurs on the final stage, so it's a slog. It's also locked behind all 48 of the lesser trials (also a slog). Crazy to me that 10% of the achievements are tied to one challenge which features no randomisation. It's repetitive & boring. More weird design choices.
OST is absolutely fantastic, to the point that you want to do runs to listen to the music. Big fan of RoR2, RoRR is a great gem and as fun as the previous title.
Extremely fun. An interesting take on a beloved classic.
Personally? Not a favorite.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I never got into the original Risk of Rain. I tried it once and it didn't click. I love this remake, though. 

The impending "rainstorm" that approaches during each run forces you to make decisions on going fast or staying to gather more power to face the storm. Every 5 minutes, the difficulty increases, making monsters healthier, more abundant, and hit harder. Fortunately, there's a ton of power to be had in items pickups, and there's no limit to how many you can carry. There are also further ways to customize your run with unlockable abilties, characters, items, and "artifacts" that dramatically alter each run. 

The game is abound with Quality of Life improvements over the original, such as only requiring the boss of each stage to be killed, and a camera zoom option. Difficulty options and adjustments are also a welcome change, providing good spots for newbies to enjoy the action while they learn the ropes. There is also a new gamemode called "Providence Trials," featuring small platforming/combat challenges that unlock new abilities and items. Some of these are really cleverly designed, but also really tough. 

My frustrations are mostly of the "git good" variety. Bosses hit really hard. You don't get many invincibility frames between hits, so you can die quickly that way too. Some characters are really hard to play, intentionally weak, or gimmicky, lending themselves to group play or challenge runs. 

Recommended to everyone. You can make the game extremely easy, so almost anyone can enjoy it. Handicaps can even be set on a per-player basis so it doesn't ruin a co-op experience.

I have played ror1, and i can say this is a massive step-up in quality; it would deserve the 15$ price, if it weren't for several glaring issues.

1. Enemies are too tanky. Plain and simple.

2. While "Providence Challenges" are a cool idea, many have issues regarding difficulty and map design, and seem to default to Monsoon difficulty and cannot be changed. This presents little benefit to newer players, who would otherwise have a less grindy way to unlock skins and skills.

3. Gameplay is still very clunky, despite the new control schemes. Just please let us shoot up.

4 .Enemies are still too tanky,

I'd love for anyone to tell me i'm missing some critical thing, so i can enjoy this game. 
But for now, i just can't recommend it.

Before Risk of Rain blew up with its 3D incarnation there was it's cult hit 2D predecessor and if you never got the chance to dip into that version Returns truly goes back to its roots. For fans of the 2D version though this is very much an 'enhanced' re-release than a true 2D sequel.

If you own the first game you're going to be very familiar with Returns at first glance. Everything that was in the first 2D game is all here just with a healthy portion of new additions and upgraded sprites. It feels very much like they wanted to cash in on the new audience while giving those who didn't vibe with the 3D version a little something extra to justify the re-purchase.

Don't get me wrong, the new content is welcome. You have a variety of fun challenges for each class which unlock alternate abilities, and everything that there can be more of has more of it from player characters and bosses to maps, items, and monsters - though it feels like playing the base game with a bunch of packaged DLC.

Personally I really loved the first 2D Risk of Rain and never got into the hype for the 3D version so I'm happy for more of the same. The enhancements, additional content, rule and content customisation, game modes, and everything else make this a clear upgrade over the original but it doesn't do much to distinguish itself beyond the extras. Even so, I'm having a blast and will continue to chip away at this through the year. If you're looking for more rain it's here, but there's no risk of new innovations for better or worse.

Risk of Rain Returns suffers most from difficulty scaling and balancing in core gameplay, with Providence Trials being a massive hit or miss. And while these problems are adjustable with the damage taken and damage received modifiers, the default scaling which most players will use, is middling up to 2 players, and abysmal with 3 or more. Enemies will spawn in too high numbers, and do far too much damage even given the additional player counts. Yet despite this, I still have fun playing Risk of Rain Returns most of the time. Perhaps not due to the difficulty, but rather the smoothness of the application of tactics with the character's movesets mastered quite well in its previous iteration. This is exemplified most in the final providence trial, which I personally believe to be the best test of skill in the game, and is so well made, that it makes me wonder what excuse certain other providence trials have. Even despite the initially daunting nature of the trial, matched with the defined constants, each run felt like it genuinely tested me to my fullest extent and rarely felt boring even after managing to clear the initial parts more and more easily. It also provided the most close-call moments, and bursts of adrenaline. It captures most of what makes Risk of Rain Returns work, when it does. The ramping dread of dealing with the overwhelming horde that might be possible to escape under the right circumstances, doubly so with friends, is ideally to me what Risk of Rain Returns is, and should be- though at its worst, it can feel like you've stumbled upon a situation which is far too dire to be dealt with, leaving only to pure frustration at the game's inflated numbers, as opposed to your own mistakes. But if you're willing to suck it up, and go on easier difficulties, and adjust settings to what you find most comfortable, playing to how you want to, Risk of Rain Returns does have a lot to offer.

For someone who has played the first Risk of Rain a bit with mods, I can safely say that this remake is well worth the money for RoR1 fans or people who are slightly interested in where the series started. One of the big improvements this game offers over the original is the ability to use the RoR2 controls which work pretty well especially with the mouse aiming. Another thing I have to commend Hopoo for are the brand new items introduced here. I'm especially a big fan of Prophet's Cape and Substandard Duplicator especially given the overall item balance here as just one of these items can really define a good run depending on if you try to loop to see how far you can get or by trying to tackle the final level and getting that sweet bit of survivor lore. With everything good I've said about this game, there is one issue I do have and it comes with the alternate skills some survivors have. There's some really cool ones like Enforcer's Shield Dash and HAN-D's DISASSEMBLE but then there are ones that while cool in theory, feel a bit too gimmicky to use. A problem I feel that RoR2 also has with some alternate skills. One other thing I would like to see is have some form of incentive to go for the final level like Eclipse returning with some (better) modifiers to really test true veterans or people who have invested quite some time into the game. Overall, Risk of Rain Returns is definitely worth checking out as a fan of the series and is a fantastic send off for Hopoo leaving the IP in the hands of Gearbox. Thank you for making such a wonderful series.

Having trouble enjoying this one. In my opinion, it's very unwieldy and awkward to control your character and aim your attacks. Dealing with flying enemies, for example, can be extremely painful, and dealing with swarms can take a long time if you don't want to die, due to constantly having to reposition. Additionally, it seems like it's considerably more common to end up in an unrecoverable run due to RNG or other factors that you have minimal control over. Obviously, both of these issues can be mitigated by playing more and understanding the game better, but I really don't feel compelled to spend my time doing that when I haven't had fun in close to ten hours of gameplay thus far.

There's a few other issues that hamper my enjoyment, but I don't really believe they're responsible for my dislike of this game so far. You can likely find some of them outlined in other negative reviews.

More detailed review
Background
I really enjoyed the original Risk of Rain, but I did feel it had its flaws. At times it felt a little too RNG based and punishing. As such, despite putting in hundreds of hours and really liking it, I think I only beat the final boss a three times.
Risk of Rain 2 is clearly a great game, but not for me. I have much less experience with shooters and Combined with RoR's time mechanic it was just too stressful.

They did not change too much between this game and the original, but what they did I feel had a big impact to make it play much better and remove frustration. The two biggest changes are updating the level maps and removing the need to kill every enemy before leaving on the teleporter. All the maps seem a little smaller and some, such as the dried lake bed, seem much less annoying to go across, especially when you start near the teleporter and have to double back to it after picking up loot. Then, because you don't have to kill every enemy once you activate the teleporter you aren't spending as much precious time tracking down the last few random Lemurians who are back on the other side of the map walking against a wall. This makes it much easier to pick up a handful of useful items and still get out of the first map before the difficulty gets to Medium which sets you up much better for a successful run.
They also adjusted the drop rates and what items start out unlocked. Some items that were originally behind difficult or very RNG based achievements now start in the pool. There also seems to be slightly more chests. While it can still happen, I don't feel it is as common to teleport in and have to walk for minutes before finding anything. Also, the color coding of certain chests can be nice, although realistically, other than the orange barrels that hold the Usable items you will try to open everything you can regardless of the color.
While I feel both of these changes do make the game easier over all, it is mostly by removing elements that made the game more annoying and less about removing the over all challenge. Also, if you do find the game too easy now, there are a lot of ways to adjust the difficulty to make it potentially much harder (or shift it in the other direction to make it even easier).

The one aspect that I am mixed on are the Providence Trials, new challenge levels that the game introduced. I really liked the idea behind them. Stages with a unique objective and set of restrictions or modifications. Many also serve to introduce new attacks for the different characters, which you then unlock after you complete the trial. Some of them were really fun and original and I enjoyed pushing myself to complete them or even get the max possible result. Unfortunately, the design quality was not uniform. The first few are super easy, which helps you learn the basics, but some of the later ones are really frustrating coupling a difficult task with a timer that seams way to short. Also, the way they unlock means that some characters it is really easy to unlock there alternate attacks while others it seems pointlessly much harder. However, the challenge itself is the main reason to play them since, while the idea of alternate attacks is cool, most I have not found that useful, and they all have a secondary way you can unlock them by just playing the game normally.
In many ways, I enjoy this game more than Risk of Rain 2.

ROR2 captivated me with the unique characters, item mechanics, and possibilities for clutch plays. There was a lot of room for skill-based maneuvering that made it fun. Even if you had bad items, if you were good you could handle most things, which caused me to slip 700h into that game.

This game, on the other hand, is a massive letdown. Speaking from the perspective of Mercenary: gun damage is scaled down considerably, so you end up shooting enemies with basic attacks for overly long periods of time. Special and accessory skills are less game-changing and more small damage boosts. This effectively results in you having to train monsters back and forth in almost rhythmic patterns while waiting for their damage to accumulate/kill them. It becomes super boring and there's little room for complex maneuvering with the basic utility skills which don't change in midair like ROR2. 

And yeah, I'm sure as you get to endgame you'll become an unkillable monster of sorts thanks to item buildup. But before then? It's just a chore tbh, it's not fun, and I'll pass. One could argue uncomplicated movement is an inherent limitation of the 2D genre itself but imo RORR makes no attempt to ameliorate this flaw.

I have mixed feelings about this game, especially as someone who's put a ton of time into Risk of Rain 2, and still enjoys firing that game up now and then. The aesthetic aspects of this game are pretty top-notch, the animations and everything give this game so much more personality than Risk of Rain 2. I was pretty addicted to it at first, but after a while it started to feel like I wasn't actually getting better at the game, I was just gambling until I happened to get the right combination of items. I say this after even finishing several runs on both Rainstorm and Monsoon with Huntress, Commando, Pilot, Mercenary, and Sniper.

Here's why I think that. It's significantly more difficult than Risk of Rain 2 and the timer matters so much more, and yet many maps are incredibly huge, which encourages you to get going to the next stage instead of exploring and looting more thoroughly. There are good improvements to many items  that have carried over to this game, and cool and interesting new items, but generally speaking, items feel much less impactful, especially when it comes to damage. To make things worse, you don't have mechanics like scrap and 3D printers to combat the RNG and improve the lacking aspects of your build. There's no proc chaining like in 2 either, which if you don't know basically involves items triggering other items, resulting in huge amounts of screen-wiping damage. With all these factors at play, I found myself struggling to deal enough damage to survive most of my runs. Attaining that feeling of being overpowered and unstoppable is so much more difficult to do, I think to this game's detriment.

One thing that allowed you to combat the RNG and the timer in Risk of Rain 2 was your ability to avoid attacks. Even if you didn't have a ton of mobility items, you would have three dimensions and cover from various objects to avoid attacks, and many characters also had a get-of-jail-free card in the form of a mobility or invulnerability skill that you could rely on to get out of a sticky situation. But if you're not lucky enough find mobility in Returns (which happened to me pretty often), you have very few options. Your base run speed very slow, your jump height is very low, there's platforms but you're often fighting on completely flat surfaces with nothing to protect you from enemies or projectiles,  and your get-of-jail-free card is often extremely lacking, either because you can barely use it due to a long cooldown timer, or because it barely takes you anywhere (like Huntress' Blink).

While I applaud Hopoo for getting creative with item and ability unlocks through Providence Trials (this is very similar to Smash Bros. Melee's Event mode), I found many of them frustrating. The unlock challenges are also a lot more character-specific than in 2, so as someone who hates playing characters like Engineer, I'll be left out of potentially hugely helpful items in my runs just because I don't enjoy playing certain characters (even knowing this I still can't be bothered). I don't like being forced into a particular play style, or feeling like I have to do something that feels like a chore in order to unlock something. (Meanwhile, I've stuck to the characters I like in 2 the entire time and I have basically every item unlocked). Some challenges are also unreasonably difficult, like the Miner challenge to unlock Shattering Justice. This is a problem that I wish Hopoo had learned from 2, with absurd and frustrating challenges like Mercenary's Ethereal and Commando's Incorruptible marring an otherwise great game.

I hesitate to give this game a thumbs-down, especially Hopoo clearly put a lot of effort and care into this. It's absolutely not a bad game, don't get me wrong. The 50-ish hours of playtime I've got out of it is great value from a $14.99 game as well. But that being said, once I beat this game on Monsoon with a few characters, my enthusiasm for it died a lot. I rarely think about coming back to it even though there are still plenty of things to unlock because the runs often feel like a slog, and like I mentioned earlier, the game generally feels like more of a gamble than a test of skill. In hindsight, I think the challenge I set for myself to beat Monsoon was really the main reason why I kept playing, and that I stopped having fun with it much earlier. The fact that a lot of Risk of Rain channels on YouTube have gone right back to Risk of Rain 2 after just a few months, despite this being a much more recent release I think says a lot.

If you haven't played Risk of Rain 2 yet, I would recommend trying that out first. If you've played 2 and you're interested, then you'll get some fun out of it, as long as you understand that it's going to be a somewhat different experience. It just doesn't have the same replayability or fun factor that 2 had in my opinion.

A fantastic revisit to Risk of Rain, the game changes little from the original 2013 release, there is a plethora of new content, items, stage variants, challenge modes, and a few new bosses as well.

One of the most impactful changes made to the game was in the fact that all characters, some more successfully than others, can move whilst firing, where Huntress used to be the only character who could before. Additionally directional aiming was a nice addition post launch.

The only gripe I can think of is the fact this game is a metroidvania platformer with such a bafflingly poor system for vertical stage traversal makes the more convoluted maps more difficult to explore, this is mainly to do with the underlying foundations of gameplay from the original risk of rain, and nothing could be done as it is a problem with that game as well.

Regardless, this will be from now on my preferred method of revisiting this game, and I plan to continue putting in hours for a long time in an attempt to finish all achievements, the game is extremely enjoyable and I would say is a flawed but stellar game that anyone who loves 2D platformers and Risk of Rain 2 should try.

It includes additional content from Risk of Rain 2 and entirely new stuff, more characters, more maps (and variants), more artifacts, alternate abilities for each character and more items.
The difficulty also remains from ROR1 and the new Providence Trials are brutally difficult, IMO there are too many unlocks locked behind this mode, which is my only major criticism. A game hasn't made me rage this much since... well since Risk of Rain 1. :)

If you liked the original Risk of Rain it's a must-buy, no questions asked.
If you haven't tried the original Risk of Rain, it might be hit or miss since it's more of a niche game than 2.

RoR:R is an all-around improvement upon the original RoR that does a good job of modernizing the source material without sacrificing its reputation for difficulty. At times, one could even describe RoR:R as "unfair", but in a charming classic/retro roguelike kinda way more than a design oversight kinda way. 
The new characters and items are a blast, the RoR2 carryovers and other misc. adjustments feel great on the game, the Providence Trials add fun side-content that fills out the game just a bit more. Plus, the new sprites are gorgeous and the new Stage 5 teleporter music in particular is awesome. 
All in all, you could do much, much worse for the price. If you're a fan of roguelikes, give this one a try.

If you're coming from RoR2, you have to understand that RoR:R is an entirely different beast. RoR:R feels like it holds your hand less, and you have to make more intricate tactical decisions (do I fight this boss, do I run away, do I wait for items, etc.). That being said, the massive bosses can at times seem difficult or even unfair to dodge, leading to some deaths that feel unearned.

Even so, Risk of Rain: Returns has all the hallmarks of the fantastic Risk of Rain design that Hopoo has cultivated over the years. The characters feel fun and interesting to play. The new and ported characters feel look gorgeous. The new Providence Trials make RoR:R feel like whole other games. And of course, the work of the legendary Chris Christodoulou cannot be understated. The new tracks are fantastic.

Even if you don't know about Risk of Rain, this is still a worthy pick-up.
(Not to mention, the multiplayer actually uses the Steam API, which is a welcome addition since apparently RoR1 didn't have that...)

This game is what I needed the OG risk of rain to be. Almost every complaint you could have for the first entry is fixed here. At least to my untrained eyes. 

The inclusion of vertical aiming does wonders for this type of gameplay. 
I also enjoy the efforts to make multiplayer more accessible. It's way easier to set up an online lobby than in OG Risk of Rain.

The updated art style is a nice touch to. I enjoy how things look more defined and well-thought out than how they did in the original.

The movement and overall game-feel is sooo much better here. Everything feels as smooth as butter to control. 

There is more content to digest here as well. Not only with the introduction of the Trials of Providence but other things like more items to unlock, More challenges, and more characters! 

Overall I rate this game 9/10. It's a much needed reboot to a classic.

Risk of Rain Returns is a huge step up compared to the previous game. But in its current state, I would not recommend this game to other people. The game has a lot of good points. The pixel art is superb. In fact, it would not be an exaggeration to say that this game has the best artstyle among other games that use pixel art. It would say that the pixel art in this game is on par with Celeste, which has pretty much the best pixel art in my opinion. The soundtrack is amazing (of course it is. It is composed by Chris Christodoulou). There is a bunch of new content, including alt abilities, new items, new stage variants, new enemies, etc. But beyond these, there are a lot of issues with the game that really ruin the experience for me. Some of them are:
1. There is no quick restart/back to character selection button
2. The new scaling is even worse than OG risk of rain. Now, it doesn't matter if you play on drizzle or on monsoon, the teleporter on third stage will always spawn 2 boss enemies, something that doesn't happen in ROR1. Also, activating the teleporter spawns way too many enemies. In ROR1, at third stage on rainstorm when the timer is around 7-8 minutes, about 4-5 enemies spawn every 10 seconds. IN RORR however, 7-8 enemies spawn every 5-6 seconds under the same conditions. In other words, the game spawns too many enemies during the teleporter, which is not really ideal. Also, apparently the multiplayer scaling is hell, which I won't comment about because I haven't played this game in multiplayer
3. The QoL features in this game are just the bare minimum. No stat hud, cannot access the logbook from the pause menu, no save system, the list just goes on. These are suggestions that have been made multiple times for both ROR1 and ROR2 over the years. One would expect that the devs will add them to their new game but no.  The aren't there. And before someone says that these can be added by modders, no game dev should rely on modders for adding basic features that should be present in the game. It doesn't matter if it's bethesda or ubisoft or some indie studio. The features listed above are very basic and should be present in singleplayer games at the very least
4. Bugs. And very basic ones at that. There are a bunch of bugs and softlocks that will make you wonder if the game was playtested enough. Certain utility skills clipping the player out of bounds, certain skill not working in tandem with other skills on a certain character although it should and a lot more. You can head to the discord server where you will find a lot more of these bugs that should make you think if the game was playtested enough
5. Providence trials. Not that they are really difficult and stuff like that (some of them are annoying). It is the fact that the game unlocks more trials as you finish the previous trial. I accept I have skill issue but at the very least let me tap out of a trial and move on to the next one locked behind it. Everyone has different skill level. I was able to complete the trial [spoiler] hot rope hop [/spoiler], which a lot of the folks on the discord say is very hard, on my second attempt but it took me 10 tries to complete the trial where you [spoiler] play as the drone [/spoiler]. Even now, I tried both the trials again couple days ago and found the former easy. My point is that there should have been a system to allow the player to skip the current trial and move on to the next locked one as long as the player has unlocked the appropriate characters
6. No alternate endings cutscene for [spoiler]acrid. I think it is well accepted that acrid was captured and trapped in the void. With this in mind, I expected a different ending cutscene for acrid, showing how he got captured.[/spoiler] To my disappointment, there wasn't one. [spoiler] I think artificer should also have one but I don't know the in depth lore so I won't say too much about her[/spoiler]
7. Skins. All the skins that the game offers are recolors. I think the [spoiler]judgement skin is a bit more than a recolor but all it does is add 3 dots over the player's head and switch the color palette to make them look like providence.[/spoiler]. I get that not all skins can be unique because the sprite work would take a lot of time but at least make the secret ones more than recolors. There are secret [spoiler] prismatic skins for a few characters that you can unlock. These are also recolors and don't change the character looks by a lot. [/spoiler] At least make these skins unique and more than just recolors. It really feels like a kick in the teeth to obtain a secret that is so lack lustre. Again, modders can add these things but it shouldn't be the job of modders to add content that should be in the base game in the first place
I won't comment on any characters feeling too weak or some items feeling too weak because I am ready to accept it is a skill issue on my part. But the above problems should be addressed quickly. I will change my review once these are fixed but for now, I would not recommend this game to anyone
Edit: Now that I have played a bit more, I will add more points
1. The last and the hardest providence trial is just not rewarding enough. All you get is a secret skin that is again a recolor. At least give me some other good stuff like unique passive skill for the characters you have beaten the trial with. Moreover, completing this trial is necessary to 100% the game. Eclipse mode exists in ROR2. Though it doesn't give you anything on beating it but it is totally optional. The said providence trial isn't.
2. The amount of new content. More specifically the lack of new stages (not variants). How come there are no new stages. Compared to ROR1, there are no new stages, hidden or otherwise. Come on now. New survivors are good and all but you have to add some new stages
3. There are no dedicated animations for attacking while jumping for any of the characters, which is off putting in the case of most characters. This is just a visual bug and doesn't affect gameplay
The game feels polished but rushed at the same time. It is clear to me that this game wasn't playtested enough. I don't understand how the devs decided to not release this game in early access first or delay the release to playtest the game more

I had big hopes for Risk of Rain Returns, after all, I have played nearly 500 hours in Risk of Rain 2. It is one of my all time favorites. However, I cannot recommend this game in its current state. Maybe future updates will solve some of the many, many issues that currently exist, but as it stands, the game is buggy (I just got stuck permanently in a wall with no way to continue the game) and in many ways is a step back in game design from Risk of Rain 2. The levels are difficult to navigate, not in a way that is challenging but in a way that is obnoxious. Movement speed is far too low considering the maps are giant and the point of the game is to collect items from random chests scattered over the map in the shortest amount of time possible. By far the largest step in the wrong direction comes in the form of how items work. There are no scrappers which means you are left completely to chance when it comes to the items available on each stage. This leads to the feeling that you have no control over your game as even if you collect every chest in a relatively short period of time the enemies will still quickly become bullet sponges who can end your run almost instantly if you make even one wrong move, and you will be making wrong moves because your control will disconnect and lag out at random intervals. It almost happened so frequently that I thought it was a feature. One last major criticism is that often the 2d maps will have some background features that look exactly like they are in the foreground and able to be used by the player and vice versa. The only way to tell what can be used as a platform or a wall is to try and run into it since the artwork gives almost no hints as to whether it is usable or not. This game is disappointing and the developers should be sad with themselves. They went from a great game with solid game play, map design, and strong art direction to one that is nearly unplayable and simply annoying to try and sink time into. I cannot recommend that anyone plays this game. I am very sorry to say that.

Basically, you cannot aim in the sky, you are going to be heavily reliant on your shift button to dodge enemies, Keep levelling up, and pick up EVERYTHING you possibly can. 

Great game, setting new boundaries for a 2D platformer, roguelike.
You get logs, you get stats, you get unlockables thanks to your in-game progress. There's very little not to love :? [i haven't found them yet]
You get coins and other currency for every single enemy you defeat, and it's magnetized to your existence, as far as I've seen. Spend the coins throughout each level to gain upgrades, new weapons, mods, equipment, ETC.

I play ROR2 key layout, and love it. Will test with a gamepad eventually, as i shmaaak a lekker sit back and don't keyboard-mouse time, but I'm pretty sure you will have fun.
You can jump and shoot, 
You can use the terrain to hide / be unhittable
But you get many enemies. The longer you last the more swarmed you become.

Level design and graphics are gorgeous to look at. There are relics/shrines/containers to open/Containers to pay to unlock/ weapon assortments of which you pick 1, The world is always rich to help your success. Sometimes you will see the worst synergy of pick ups vs character, but that's within your hundreds of hours of play.

Difficulty in these games are based on how long are you currently alive in our world. Are you really going to get further?
The AI that taunts you is always getting stronger. In Easy/normal start/ you are facing shielded baddies from wave 2/ after your first two creeps. 
Creatures spawn out of everywhere, and some can travel through the terrain in their flying state. Each monster has unique methods of moving, and makes you need to shift dodge and build a habit if you want to Survive.

Normal mode gets harder the longer you stay alive, but it starts pretty slow. Tsunami mode is hardcore, but you will make money much faster in comparison.
Money does not transfer to the next levels.
Boss fights are when you activate the exit level trigger. You have an amount of time you must last while the whole level's upgraded creatures are thrown at you to survive. 

Controls of ROR2 :
EQ - equipment :) that you pick up,
Left click - Standard weapon,
Right click - Special weapon
Shift - Dodge mechanic 
R for something of a combo shot,
WASD - Movement 
Space - Jump

The items you pick up, are siiiiiiick; try to never leave a level without having bought everything..
You should also memorize everywhere you go in a level to prevent missing out on stuff. Some levels will puzzle you.

This is only the beninging, there's going to still be many updates to this gorgeous beauty.

I must address some "problems" with the review , before more confused individuals keep commenting . I like the niche mechanics and irksome aspects of the game, I enjoy the tedious movement and gameplay, but I am not gonna recommend it to the majority of people, for obvious reasons. If you do not know what 'obvious' means, google it.
I am also kicking the vote down to a 6 from 7, because it still has many issues, some of which were patched (I will most likely increase the score in the future when they release more updates), but some of the issues still persist and should've never been released. Also, this way all the people still finding their way around the concept of what a review is can stop complaining that I down-voted a game with a score of 7.
For everyone else commenting 'skill issue' or not understating the paragraphs above, ask ChatGPT to translate it for you.


[h1] The Review [/h1]

The remake of Risk of Rain 1, or the modernised version as it has been advertised, does a lot of things right while also doing a lot of things wrong. I am enjoying the game, but they left in so many issues from the original.

[h1] The improvements [/h1]

You can finally strafe while attacking
No need to kill all enemies for the teleport to unlock.
The graphics and audio design are so much better. I can't notice much difference in the remastered soundtrack, but the in-game audio and visuals are fantastic.
New survivors, items, artifacts, enemies and unlockable alternate abilities added.
Better multiplayer system makes it easier to play with friends.
Manually crafted "mini-games" in the form of Providence Trials.
The game is definitely harder than the original or RoR2, depending on who you are that might be a good thing or not.

[h1] Now for the truck load of things they either did not bother to change or made worse [/h1]

[strike] Still no way to quickly change your direction of attack, either by double tapping direction key or using a mouse or any other way to do it. You have to stop, change direction and start attacking. It's not difficult to get used to it, but it is bothersome most of the time. [/strike] This has been patched
No animation cancelling, meaning you have to wait until an ability finishes casting in order to press another one, otherwise the game will completely ignore your second key input. Commando seems to be the only one not affected by this as much.
Bosses can drop equipment instead of items, which makes no sense especially how often it happens, this invalidates the usage of mountain shrines. Instead of making your life harder for better rewards, you make it harder to receive 2+ equipment drops. There should be a limit on how many equipment drops/equipment chests you can receive per stage.
Out of combat items do not activate while on ropes/vines. You have to either get off the vine or wait until the item activates and then start climbing.

Stages are made to waste your time. Some are way to big to traverse, especially on characters with no mobility. Others do not have a full loop mechanic, meaning if you fall down you have to traverse the rest of the map to go back up, Sunken Tombs being one of them. 
In addition to the big maps, there will sometimes be a max of 2 chests and other times you will get 3 useless drones or 5 shrines which drop nothing. Coupled with a map like Damp Caverns, which has so many layers and is bigger than most, you will waste so much time searching for a chest that it's far more worth to just skip it all together. 
Still no indicator on what number stage you are. This is not that big of an issue, but it would make it easier for people who want to 100% the game and gather all logs.

Now that enemies can climb ropes, plus enemies that teleport into you and the new enemies that dive-bomb you, makes kiting really important and harder to do. This reaches a point where, you need to articulate your movement in such a way to dodge everything or you get oneshot by certain mobs. Especially on higher difficulties like Monsoon, it feels more like a chore and I know some people like doing this (me included sometimes), but for most it's not a great time and it gets tedious rather quickly.

There are a lot more issues, I will just quickly list a few of them.
[list]
[*] Enforcer not blocking AOE, pierce attacks or even enemies standing in you.
[*] [strike] Huntress auto-aim is more of a nuisance than being of any help [/strike] This has been patched
[*] Artificer simply sucks and is not fun to play
[*] Certain multi-hit abilities do not proc items multiple times
[*] Providence trials are fun for the most part, but some are absolutely horrendous to complete
[*] Bosses directly countering certain survivors, to a point in which you can't do anything about it.
[*] Most items are pointless, more so on other survivors
[*] Stages do not feel intuitive to travel
[*] Attacking, even if no enemy is nearby, cancels certain out-of-combat items like Red Whip and Bustling Fungus
[*] The game is capped at 60 fps and sometimes there are lag spikes pushing it down to 20-30, not that great for a 'modern' game.[/list] 

[h1] Final Thoughts [/h1]

The gameplay of the original RoR is vastly outdated. RoR Returns is basically 80% of the same game, but it does not feel and look like a browser game.
I do like the game and it is surely an improvement with a bit more content, but adding a few characters and items does not make a game better, that's just a DLC. The only important thing they fixed, is the ability to move while attacking.
I know Hopoo Games will release more patches for the game, but some of these problems should have not existed in the first place, especially when you call it a modernized version.

So should you buy it? If you loved the first game then yes. If you do not like platformers, dreadful RNG and learning gimmicky movement, then to do not buy it. If you just want to give it a try, then go for it, the game is rather cheap, but I would wait until more patches are released, before buying the game.

As it stands right now, I give it a 6/10

I FORGOT THIS GAME IS MAPLESTORY!!! Except it actually flows well with a contoller and isn't programmed on janky 2000's netcode!

So yea, if you were a mapler like me but wished for some more action, get this immediately. It was a great game back in the day, it's an OUTSTANDING game now. Good multiplayer, eye-poppingly fluid pixel art, some of the best OST tracks out of all indie games I've ever played. If you wanted to know where the genre roots of VampSurv started, check out this OG game, remastered! 

It's basically just what you see in the screenshots but tuned super well and with extreme polish and thought as to the mechanics. If they could make an ability or character feel good, they did. The gamefeel is masterclass quality. The only potential downside is that it's a bit simplistic overall but I can't really recommend RoR enough. 

And interestingly, just like Maplestory, I hated the move to 2D with the sequel but this remaster has reminded me why I loved whittling away the early morning hours with the first, red eyed and fingers twitching, just like those old Maplestory Beta days when I could get permission to use the Dial-up until my parents went to bed!

The main content is fun. Sure, that's the important part, except for all of the other important parts. The UI is kinda sucky, like Risk of Rain 2's. However, ROR2 has a mod which improves the UI by actually telling you what items do. This game doesn't even have modding support. That alone is immediate not recommendation in my opinion. However, that alone is not the reason I'm not recommending it. The side content, Providence Trials, which can hardly be considered side content because of how much it unlocks for the main gameplay, is also complete and utter bs. I'd tell you just to mod the game to make it easier for the trials, but still no mod support. Although there is no mod support, there are difficulty settings, such as the "Drizzle, Rainstorm, Monsoon" but also a little menu where you can increase the damage you deal and decrease the damage you take by a bit. The difficulty has been sharply increased from the original Risk of Rain, and I heard that 50% damage taken is much closer to the original game, but this isn't much of an issue as it can be fixed, more like a mild annoyance. I find this game fun, but I still have difficulty recommending it, though I would love to recommend it as soon as mod support is added, and perhaps the Providence Trials are tweaked.

This game is a great experience. As a returning ror2 player(on console) who dabbled a bit in ror1 I can confidently say that risk of rain returns is a perfect conclusion/installment to the series. It's like the first game, but with the best elements of the second game, and a bit of new flair thrown in as well. Even though I have only played for 10 hours I know that there is plenty more enjoyment that I have yet to experience.

Amazing job by Hopoo (as always) but also for Gearbox's first influence, really good. I am excited for any future content they are willing to offer for this game. Providence trials are a fun and interesting way to earn new items and skills, plus the inclusion of some Risk of Rain 2 things are greatly appreciated. Again another game of arcade like joy that brought me into gaming when I was a kid. I will warn people, this game is far harder than Risk of Rain 2, whether it be the change of how characters play and/or the 2D vs 3D aspect; this game presents challenges Risk of Rain 2 players took for granted. I love this game though, truly another addicting loop of gameplay to go through.

Okay, for those clueless: Risk of Rain was a game that came out in 2013. Thatâs over ten years ago, and it looks and feels pretty dated. This is a RoR remaster that pretties things up and changes a few gameplay elements to modernize things a bit. 

As for whether I recommend itâ¦thatâs a bit more complicated. This certainly has some things going for it (as I said in my original review of Risk of Rain), like easy couch co-op, a great stylized design, and a lot of variety in characters. Itâs not a bad game by any stretch, and itâll kill a few hours no problem.

On the other hand, Risk of Rain is over a decade old - and you can overhaul the graphics, but if the core of the game feels dated, modernized visuals and a new skill system wonât change anything. Sadly, I think thatâs the case here. Things fall into a weird hybrid zone where itâs too different to feel like Risk of Rain, but not different enough to feel exciting.

One of the rare reviews where I wish for a âneutralâ option. This is a passable remaster, but felt like one that came too soon, or wasnât extensive enough. If you absolutely adore these sorts of randomized run-and-guns, Iâd recommend it, but for the more casually interested I probably wouldnât.

Great remake, but overall disappointing game. To start off, I have never played Risk of Rain and only played Risk of Rain 2 before this dropped. I was quite excited to be able to experience the first game with more polish and more content, so I bought it on day one. But as you can see, I don't have nearly as many hours in the game as in the sequel, yet I feel justified to leave a review. Speaking of, my only direct comparison here is Risk of Rain 2, so that's what I'll be comparing Returns to in this review.

The first of my problems stem from the fact it's a two-dimensional game. Stages are just way too big and/or base movement speed is just way too slow, you just end up doing mostly nothing while walking to the right or left, which also means items are scattered too scarcely across the map. The problem with 2D is that you can't see where you have to go to get items or which ways are just a waste of time. The 3-dimensional gameplay of the sequel fixed this by allowing you to see very quickly where you should and shouldn't be going for items. 
Stages are also incredibly clumsy to travel, with you having to resort to climbing to reach higher places. Climbing doesn't allow you to engage in combat or do anything rather than go up or down, which obviously isn't very exciting. Of course, this issue becomes less prevalent the more movement items you get. However, getting movement items isn't guaranteed (exception being the Artifact of Command), which means you'll be slow during at least the first three stages. In Risk of Rain 2 characters never felt as slow as in this game, even when you have a few movement items. 
The stages being so large is a major factor in me not wanting to do just "one more run" like with the sequel, because runs take way too long to get exciting, which hurts replayability - off which roguelikes tend to live or die - a lot. 

Another problem with the two-dimensionality is that at some point in the mid-to-late game where a lot of enemies start spawning, it's almost impossible to see what's going on. With all the effects going on, the majority of enemies being way bigger than the player, and the enemy sprites in general just overlapping with each other it becomes near impossible to reliably avoid damage let alone know what's attacking you.

Items play a huge role in avoiding and dealing damage, but it always feels really bad to get equipment for a boss. I don't really understand why this is even a possibility, especially since stages have plenty of them already. Beating a boss should feel rewarding, and the nature of the game makes it so that items in general are very valuable. Getting equipment feels like a huge waste of time. While beating bosses is something you have to do if you want to progress, getting equipment while you already likely have one doesn't just give you nothing for beating the boss, it actively handicaps you since you could've gotten an item that would at least passively help you in some shape or form.

Providence Trials are a novel concept of unlocking items through other means than just regular runs, but there's a lot of them that aren't fun at all. It feels like they've been made as annoying as possible purely for the sake of adding artificial difficulty to unlocking new items.


While I haven't experienced the original, Returns added a ton of new content, and all of it is of very high quality. It almost makes me wish some of it would've been in Risk of Rain 2. There's new abilities for characters, new items, and new enemies. Part of me feels this could've just been a DLC and update for the original game, but I guess making it a seperate game garners more attention.
The soundtrack is once again phenomenal, with composer Chris Christodoulou remastering the original OST for the game. It has this familiar Risk of Rain vibe, but definitely feels like its own thing and is always a joy to listen to. Sound design in general is very well done and the game always looks pretty.

By the big red downward thumb you could have deduced that I don't recommend this game, and I hope that through this review it has become clear why. For me, the positives don't outweigh the negatives at all. Playing a game should never be boring or feel like a chore, and playing this game definitely does most of the time. The beginning of runs are too slow and uninteresting, while getting to late game is too confusing. While the game looks prettier than the original, and adds new content, I can't shake the feeling it could have been sold as DLC and/or a major update. They're good additions, but they're not mind-blowing pieces of content and thus don't warrant being sold as a standalone game.

The original version of the game was an indie darling, a cult-classic roguelike that was praised by almost everyone who picked it up. However, it showed its age, and at the time had quite a bit of jank associated with it, from accidentally clipping into walls and softlocking to items sometimes dropping out of the map. Plus, the controls weren't quite there for a lot of people, and the difficulty was too static, stuck somewhere between a casual breeze and a unforgiving beyond belief for the majority of players.
This version fixes just about every problem the original had. Characters control better, enemies are more responsive and more varied, the games underlying systems are more refined and more transparent, there's even more lore. All of it, stellar improvements, on top of adding just enough spice to make older players of the original have to re-assess and re-learn the game's systems. It can be genuinely unforgiving at times, but rewarding to learn and addictive once you do, and with added difficulty modifiers able to smooth out the gameplay experience for newer or less "hardcore" players.

If you tried to like RoR1 because of its great soundtrack, fun items, great atmosphere, and interesting universe, but couldn't truly love it because of its clunky gameplay, annoying navigation, and ridiculous difficulty, this game is unfortunately not going to be much more enjoyable for you.

There are wonderful graphical updates, some reworks to the soundtrack, some new characters, some new stages, and a few quality of life adjustments. Everything about the actual gameplay has remained pretty much unchanged.

It's saddening, because I really wanted to like the original, and was hoping the remake would be something I could finally get into. I was really excited to give it a try, and I tried, but I just don't feel like I'm having any fun. The worst part by far is I genuinely feel like nothing I do matters at all. I've tried prioritizing items, I lose. I've tried prioritizing time, I lose. I've tried kiting as much as possible, I lose. I've tried being aggressive, I lose. I've tried to fix the problem with the damage dealt/taken options, and it just feels like cheating. Ugh.

It's like the original, but better in every way. More enemies, environments, items, survivors, and everything  overall. The only thing I don't really like is how much more difficult the game is compared to the original, but it's honestly just a skill issue on my end.   7.5/10

A perfect remake to bring the original game into the modern age. Ten long years have passed since the release of the original masterpiece (Of which I've still failed to drown those darn whorls) and the game still holds such a grip on me. The music is perfect, the environments are cool and fun to explore, the lore is endless, rich and fun to discover, and the enemies, especially the final boss Providence, are some of the coolest and most interesting enemies to learn about in any rogue like. Tons of extra content has been added, including new characters that feel amazing to play, new extremely challenging Trials to unlock new powerful items and new ways to play survivors, and even more enemies not seen in the original, items not seen in the original, new artifacts not seen in the original, and stage layouts not seen in the original. A total update through and through. Since the release of the sequel answered some of the mystery's of this game, and left others unanswered further, I do hope the devs add on to this game with some form of expansion to explain what did happen to the Contact Light. Definitely pick this up if you want a game to play with friends that wont get old and has a satisfying learning curve.

Risk of Rain Returns serves as a commendable remaster of the original game. Despite not having played the initial installment, I found this remastered version quite impressive. However, my enthusiasm is tempered by the challenge of dealing with minuscule sprites. When characters require binoculars to be visible, it becomes a logistical issue, as I find myself without a free hand to operate the keyboard.

Furthermore, the consistent left alignment of most maps presents a navigational challenge. Venturing to the right often leads swiftly to dead ends, which can be frustrating. These design choices hinder the overall gaming experience.

Nevertheless, for aficionados of pixelated indie games, Risk of Rain Returns remains a solid choice, particularly for brief gaming sessionsâperfect for those moments spent on the toilet.

As a Risk Of Rain 2 player who was never able to get the hang of the original, this is flat-out a superior game (as a remake should be, I know).

Notable new things in the game being moving while shooting with ranged survivors + horizontal mouse aiming makes combat feel way less awkward. More survivors who weren't there in the original + more alternate abilities, enemies, and stage variants adds a booster shot to the replayability of the game.

They have also added a functioning online multiplayer, which is a nice thing to top it off.

If there's any valid negative criticism to have of the game at this point, I would say it is too big maps for the amount of chests found on said maps. Either buff the number of chests on the maps or give the player the ability to do it themselves with a gamerule option that addresses it.

This game is a worthy remaster of the first game, it not only remakes some stuff, but it adds on what RoR1 was. It adds extra settings, items, characters, etc etc.

However...one thing that didn't change are the abysmally bad controls. They. Suck. They offer to use the control scheme of RoR2 which is a nice addition and WOULD make people more comfortable with the game much quicker, but you can't aim with the mouse...
I don't expect us to be able to shoot up or something, but I was expecting to at least be able to use the mouse to...you know, aim left and right? Instead, you can't do shit with it other than shoot, which makes it do the opposite of what getting RoR2-like settings should do, they are confusing and counter intuitive.

I could not get used to playing anything other than Huntress because she just shoots whoever's closer, no matter the direction, but a character like commando or literally anyone else but huntress, just feel awkward to control.

Dear devs, let us use the mouse for directional aim. There's no excuse for how bad this feels to control.

Still recommend it tho, good game regardless of counter intuitive controls.


Edit: They did add directional aiming. I have no more complaints.

This game saved my life.

I am 41.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.
After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

The enemies have way too much health (am i shooting nuts and grain or bullets and buckshot?), which makes the combat boring and tedious. Bosses require the player to dodge to last any significant amount of time, which makes several characters simply unviable (why even add them?). The controls feel unresponsive (I frequently desperately struggled to fire off a skill in the midst of combat without it registering my inputs) and are more of an issue then enemy actions. Flying enemies get to shoot straight at you while you only get to shoot left or right, they are also frequently faster than you and their positioning makes returning fire an ordeal, completely breaking any remnants of flow the combat had to begin with. Speaking of movement: the default speed and jump height are agonizingly low and make travesing the levels unfun and the aiming being non-existent coupled with the pathetic damage dealt on hit make gunplay unfun as well. In terms of balance, some characters are completely overpowered, while others struggle with doing anything. Overall the experience can be likened to trying to skin a deer using only the blades of a plastic fan. The graphics are pretty, animations are so dynamic and snappy that they almost seem out of place in the painful grind of the game, and the sound design (music and sfx both) is actually really pleasant. 3/10, I really wish i could get a refund...

Having delved into Risk of Rain Returns, I find myself captivated by its enthralling gameplay and nostalgic yet refreshing mechanics. This sequel redefines the roguelike genre with its seamless blend of heart-pounding action, strategic depth, and addictive replayability.

From the moment I stepped into its dynamically generated worlds, I was immersed in the relentless pursuit of survival against hordes of otherworldly adversaries. The diverse roster of playable characters each brings unique abilities and playstyles, ensuring that every run feels distinct and exhilarating.

The revamped visuals and audio design breathe new life into this iconic franchise, enhancing the immersive experience while paying homage to its roots. The thrill of scavenging for loot amidst the chaos, coupled with the escalating difficulty over time, keeps the adrenaline pumping in every moment of gameplay.

What truly sets Risk of Rain Returns apart is its ingenious progression system. The time-based difficulty scaling adds an extra layer of challenge, rewarding both quick thinking and adaptability. The plethora of items and power-ups synergize in unexpected ways, allowing for thrilling combinations that can turn the tide of battle in an instant.

Moreover, the cooperative multiplayer mode amplifies the fun factor exponentially. Collaborating with friends to survive the relentless onslaught of enemies fosters camaraderie and makes for unforgettable gaming sessions.

While the game maintains its challenging nature, it never feels unfair. Each defeat only fuels the desire to jump back in, armed with newfound knowledge and strategies.

In conclusion, Risk of Rain Returns is a triumphant continuation of a beloved series, offering an electrifying and endlessly entertaining experience for both solo adventurers and co-op enthusiasts. With its seamless gameplay mechanics, diverse content, and addictive nature, this title stands tall as a must-play for anyone seeking a thrilling, replayable adventure.

I don't normally leave reviews for games but the risk of rain series is one of my absolute favourites and i was super excited to play risk of rain returns but to be completely honest if you want risk of rain 1 you should just play that, i personally find the changes to not be worth buying the game again at the minute. maybe if they change the fire while moving to have your character fire at the side of the screen your cursor is on then maybe we'll be moving in the right direction for modernising the game so to speak, but as it stands im just gonna keep playing the original version. Im still against releasing the same game again but i think there is enough new stuff that it can be justified so i am changing my review to positive because of this

In its current state I can't recommend this game. There are too many balancing problems looking at this game as a single player. Some survivors are very hard on monsoon (hard) difficulty, while others are so easy you might catch yourself daydream while playing because it requires no concentration. This alone makes it not recommendable.
One big aspect is unlocking items, other playable characters and such things. Most of these are alright, more or less complex or difficult to unlock. But some of them are actually horrible. Without guides online I would not even have a single clue to unlock some of this stuff. 
Another big aspect is movement, especially in the "trials". Which are probably the worst kind of content I've seen in a modern game. I can excuse bad mechanics or some bad movement options (climbing, huntress second utility etc.), but these trials are semi optional and unnecessarily hard and unpleasant to play, let alone master in a given time limit. Sadly most die hard fans will just say "git gud", thankfully you will rarely see these kinds of people in online mode. 

Some other problems are horrendous visual clutter, boring soundtrack (purely subjective), bad boss design (purely objective) and some normal mobs that are harder to fight in small numbers than 5 champion bosses at the same time.

As someone who got introduced to risk of rain through the original 2013 version this remaster was everything I wished for. 
Incredible graphics. Love how true they stayed true to the original but still enhanced it and made it look modern. 

Gameplay wise they added great stuff from RoR2 like alternative skills and the challenge of the mountain. It also has some complete new stuff like drone scrapping, complete new enemies and bosses. And the best of all is the fact that if youre an oldhead and just wanted to play the modern RoR you can disable all the new content.

Providence trials has been a heated topic but i enjoy the challenge a lot and think it gives you some fun alternative to the usual runs. 

If youre coming from RoR2 you should be aware that this game is a platformer and generally harder at first than RoR2. It has similar mechanics but plays differently. 

All in all i think this game is a masterpiece and is a must buy for everyone who played the original but wants better netcode, animations and less jank.

Risk of Rain was a great game that had some major technical flaws when playing online with friends. The 10 year later remaster fixes all those flaws, majorly updates the graphics, and adds a solid array of new content.

Absolutely nothing bad to say about it, one of the best roguelikes got even better.

Dang, I really like this one. When the first Risk of Rain came out, I hadn't really tried many rougelike games. I had dabbled but hadn't unlocked that type of gamer inside of me yet. So I didn't really play it at all. Fast forward a few more years and Risk of Rain 2 releases, and I had spent much more time on various rougelike games, as well as looked back on Risk of Rain fondly even though I never spent proper time with it. I spent a lot of time on RoR2 and love the hell out of that game so when I learned about the reboot I was eager to play a remaster of the original. I have had a blast relearning how to use familiar items 2D, a whole new learning experience on maneuvers, and avoiding damage. I'm so glad I came back to give RoR R a try. I can already tell I will be spending just as much time on this one as I did with RoR 2. I highly recommend playing this game. It's so fun. It can be challenging and RNGesus doesn't always answer your prayers but honestly that adds to the fun. Some of my best runs so far ended up being big builds that started off with some of the most useless items. Very fun for RoR veterans, and new players who enjoy challenging rougelikes.

I miss the 3d nature of RoR2, but I can't deny how excellent the design here is. The characters, monsters, maps, items... all *che'f kiss*
Not as fun as Risk of Rain 2, but I like shooters more than platformers and it's still very fun. Definitely worth it. I haven't played multiplayer yet so maybe that's even better.

This is a fun little Roguelike for a small price. The fun aspect of the game is the near infinite scaling of power, so that you eventually turn into a god that is flying through the levels and obliterating everything. 

HOWEVER, even though I think it is worth the money, it is still a bit disappointing. The graphics are better than ROR1, but not miles better. They are still pixelated and kinda low detail.

A lot of people point out that the controls suck, as someone who has almost 100hrs in ROR1, I kinda agree. For a 2023 game, what really stopped them from just allowing you to shoot into every direction while running around? It would have changed the first game, but maybe for the better.

The Huntress is still op because it is the only character that can properly kite enemies, don't know why they didn't just balance everything tbh.

If you like ROR2 you might like this, but maybe you won't. ROR2 is from a gameplay perspective just better designed.
They could have turned this into a completely new, polished experience. Unfortunately, it's like 80% the same game as ROR1.

I loved the original, Loved 2 but never actually played it all that much, and now I can definitely say this remake is my favourite of the bunch. All of the new challenges and abilities are an absolute joy and you can tell they were designed by a team that has played the hell out of this game and know exactly what would be cool to add. Its just a great game.

While the latest patch fixed aiming, there's still a lot of room for improvement.

My biggest gripe with this game comes down to the stages themselves, they are so big and yet feel so empty. Chests are very inconsistent, you can traverse half of the stage and not find a single one of them or you find like 5 within 20 meters of each other, there's no inbetween.

Navigating the stages is also a nightmare on its own, you have no minimap and you can get lost very easily, and don't even get me started on finding that damn Teleporter.

Platforming sucks. You fall off of ledges too easily, and that often results in you taking a lot of fall damage. Your jumps have to be very percise in order to cross gaps and get on ropes.

Enemy density is also a really big problem depending on the survivor you're playing. If your survivor has no piercing abilities or weapons, you're kinda screwed. Enemies tend to spawn in very large numbers (especially in later stages) and they can very easily overwhelm you, especially during Teleporter events where most of them are Elites. This wouldn't be such a big issue if finding chests was consistent and easy, but alas, it is not.

There's a good game underneath these issues, but until they're not fixed or improved upon, I cannot reccomend this game.

A great remaster of the original Risk of Rain. Looks gorgeous and feels great to play thanks to modern controls and some quality-of-life redesigns and tweaks. The new music tracks are just what you'd expect from Chris. I love that Hopoo adapted some RoR2 content into the game.

If you haven't played RoR1 yet, buy this version; it bears the title of "remaster" very appropriately. There's even a "Classic" ruleset to make things behave like the original. This is the complete experience.

It's no risk of rain 2, and it's so incredibly janky and strange, but this is a beautiful product of its time remastered with a lot of the bad jank fixed. Not to mention, the devs are super engaged in the community and are already making fixes to many peoples issues!

Would highly recommend, even if you've only played risk of rain 2 (or no risk of rain at all!) as it's just really really addicting, like Risk of Rain should be.

EDIT: After having played nearly 80 hours, this game is honestly just fantastic. A lot of the jank has already been fixed, and the game has an amazing difficulty curve and learning curve that I'm starting to finally master, doing Monsoon runs every time now. Would HIGHLY recommend, even if you've only played risk of rain 2!

Good remake/remaster of the first RoR. There is some new content which I really like, like the Providence Trials that re-mix the games mechanics into little challenges to unlock new alternate abilities and costumes for characters. It's not even just straight up challenge levels, they got really creative with some of these (there's a goddamn recreation of Castlevania). They also added content from RoR2, namely characters and monsters.

Graphics got prettied up a bit, so did the soundtrack.

All in all, a recommend. I didn't play the first time much, and only played RoR2 a couple of times with friends. But I got fairly addicted to Returns, so take that as you will.
Remember, if you died in a run it's because your drops were bad, not that you are bad

I did play a bunch of ror2 but I only have 50 hours in return so I won't voice my opinions on item or character balance.

[h3]What I enjoy more in return[/h3]
[list]
[*][b]Teleporter[/b] : You rush it, then you loot the stage, most of the time you finish the event and looting at the same time. (feel more proactive)
[*][b]No scrappers and printers[/b] : They're not present which mean you don't spend 5 mins printing and scrapping items to get 10 crits lenses. (less downtimes!)[spoiler] no recycler either to create down time because you so so need that specific red item.[/spoiler]
[*][b]Drones[/b] : They feel waaaay stronger, upgrading them at a station or scrapping them is quite fast too.
[*][b]Ai[/b] : Most locals can't follow you everywhere, which mean you can just run to the other side of the map and lose half of them if needed.
[*][b]Ropes[/b] : love em. :)
[*][b]Dying in multiplayer[/b] : You can now loot items as a drone and piss on enemies so dying doesn't mean youre going to lose 10 items.
[*][b]Looping[/b] : You don't have to do a full loop to go to the final boss. After every teleporter events they let you go there.
[*]Temporary items are nice.
[*]I like the last stage more.
[*]Not a single boss has a "hide from me mechanic". (almost undodgable laser beam, sun ,supernova...)[spoiler] lame mechanics, Ifrit walls are kinda annoying though.[/spoiler]
[/list]
[h3]What I like in Ror2[/h3]
[list]
[*][b]Itemization[/b] : Lunar items, void items, scrappers and printers aren't present so your average run is more luck based.
[*][b]Newt[/b] : Newt was a great way to pause the game in multiplayer.
[*][b]Eclipse[/b] : Isn't there but it's fine since we got the final trials instead.
[*][b]Mods[/b] : The game is older so obv there's more mods.
[/list]

I normally don't review steam games but this is one I think everyone should try. You can clearly see all the love and passion that Hopoo Games put into this game through things like the beautiful art, the amazing gameplay, and all of the fun little extra things to see and learn about the world this game takes place in.
