This game is so true to the original but in a bad way. I don't want to take the time to organize a well written review because I am still digesting how conflicted I feel about the games current state. So instead I will rant about things I hate now, then come back when the game settles into it's more "final" form. 

- So much RNG it causes more bad than good. Or more specifically, the inconsistency of every run. By stage 2 I can feel like the run is a wash because of low/bad drops. Up the loot quantity?

- Multiplayer (my desired way to play) is a hot mess. Bosses only drop 1 item for all players. Why?! Loot hardly scales to number of players, drought all game. Accidentally walking over items or playing with forced item share is NOT fun. Trying to keep the items equal between players is a chore. Why not be the first risk to drop items out of inventory?

- Elites. Why are elites so damn common on any stage at any difficulty? I will go through stage 1 and wipe the boss in seconds, only to get hung up on a lightning elite proving to be WAY more of a boss fight that the portal boss. 

- Is that a ledge I can stand on? No...

- Lava portal boss Cremators can be a run ender just for existing. 

- Items feel really weak aside from a select few and are few and far between. 

- Need more range on TP particles for ease of tracking down.

- Some characters skills (most) are, in all cases, worse than the alternative. 

To be clear, enjoying the game. Just feel like this love letter game to RoR 1 could have been modernized. Still playing, still digesting.

What can I say? I detailed my list of demands for a positive review, just like a few others, and they delivered.

While they didn't add completely free aiming, which was what I really wanted, they did add free directional aiming that is completely disconnected from your movement. Considering how badly I think totally free aiming would mess up game balance unless they allowed monsters to move much more freely, this is about as good as they can do without making major changes to the game.

They also gave slower characters more movement speed, one of my biggest gripes and the easiest to fix. I was certain they weren't going to do anything about that, but they did, and it's awesome. 

I still stand by what was probably my second biggest complaint, which is that the printers and scrappers from ROR2 deserve to be here. They were genius run-savers, and it's a shame that they somehow missed that addition when they added so many other items from the second game. Who knows, though, with how things are looking now, that may very well be added some point in the future, and it isn't enough to truly take away from the fact that they fixed my other major complaints.

Hopefully, at least the scrappers and printers will make an appearance because I desperately want them, but it still gets a thumbs up for giving me just about everything they could that I asked them for.

Alot of negative reviews are expecting this game to be too much like RoR2 and while there is obviously similarities the way in which combat encounters play out is not going to be the same. Instead of rewarding target priority, it rewards crowd control and positioning, it is satisfying in its own way to bunch a big pack of enemies up and pop them with your full arsenal of abilities. 

Some of the complaints just seem very uninformed to me or stem from skill issues, like saying the alternate abilities are bad or that Miner is somehow worse than the original. Complaints about aiming being stiff with mouse controls are valid but the impact this actually has on gameplay is overexagerrated. 

Its also worth mentioning that the game improves not just on the original but also on RoR2's mechanics in some ways. One big change is the removal of the teleporter bubble/needing to kill every enemy from RoR2/RoR1 respectively. This adds alot of flexibility in how you can approach the teleporter, and lets you use the 90 second timer to scavenger for a few more chests if you so desire without being forced to just sit in one area like RoR2. Also, players in multiplayer turn into drones upon death and can still pick up items, which is an excellent way of ensuring players who die early do not always fall behind the power curve (another big issue in RoR2).

Overall as someone who did not like RoR1 and liked RoR2 but got burnt out of it, I am enjoying this game, but I am not sure I will play it as much as RoR2 overall. It still has the same fun of getting a cracked build as RoR2 and wiping out everything in sight but some parts of the game feel outdated (such as bosses which can be very easily cheesed). Multiplayer being highly accessible like in RoR2 is definitely a huge boon though. If you like RoR2 then there is a good chance you will like this but don't expect it to feel the same as RoR2 or other 2D rouge-likes, this game is its own beast.

I never played ROR1 and have put a lot of time into the second game, so I thought I had an idea of what I was getting myself into but didn't expect this game to be as hard as it is.

Honestly I do a lot of complaining below so I might as well say some positives... Well its Risk of Rain, so I already like it, but I like how they brought a lot of stuff from 2 into this game. However, even though I haven't played 1 I like how there's unique items, maps, and enemies in this game. It for sure keeps it fresh. I also like how the music is similar but not exact, like sky meadows I thought it was the same song but it changed up quickly. Speaking of music it's (as always) beautifully crafted and I just can't get enough of Chris Christodoulou's beautiful art. As well the graphics are amazing compared to 1. Pixel art really is the best because you can be so creative, I'll always love it most. At first I did like that skills can be unlocked via Providence Trial or simply challenges like "kill x enemies." I really do like this and some of the trials are really cool and unique.....

....but the bad ones are absolutely awful. And of course some awful ones can only be completed by trial. Maybe it's a skill issue but "Hot-Rope Hop", "Routine Maintenance", "Go On Without Me", and Judgement were the absolute worst. If I weren't achievement hunting and wanted the skills I would've skipped them. I loved that from ROR2, having achievements with skills locked behind it with a very specific challenge. But wow these suck. I'm here for the roguelike not the minigames..Also there are some cool challenges but there's also a lot of niche skills that feel they were made just for the challenge and not the roguelike. Specifically Artificers Pulse Spear.

Maps are way too big and characters are way too small in the beginning. I feel more inclined to play on Artifact of Command just so I can start with a red whip sooner(which is so good in this game). The first couple levels are unbearable because of how long it takes to find the teleporter and more items at times. Hoping Hopoo will release a patch soon that will make it so you can see the particles of the teleporter better. 2D really makes it hard to find. Luckily as I'm editing this they just released a patch that makes it so you can aim with your mouse and bosses don't drop equip items. Slowly but surely fixing the small problems I had with the game haha.

But regardless of the complaints I still have a good time. I don't like it better then ROR2 but it's still an enjoyable experience even with its downsides. I feel I'm so critical because I enjoy the franchise so much and I want to see it be it's best.

The OG Risk of Rain, but better. 

Must play for Roguelite fans. If you're coming from RoR2, playing in two dimensions is a bit of an adjustment, and the game does have a steep learning curve. Fortunately, you've got plenty of ways to play, from dropping the difficulty down to drizzle or using artifacts like "Command" to make the game more approachable. 

The amount of un - lockable's really sets this remaster apart from the original. Alternate abilities that often "fix" characters flaws, skins, items, more survivors,there is plenty of meta - progression here. Providence trials while a mixed bag (some of them are infuriating) are an overall really cool experience culminating in a ridiculously challenging, but engaging, final challenge. 

Seriously a wonderful game, would recommend it to anybody who's fine with some level of challenge. I'm unsure if Hopoo game's has any intention of continually updating the game, as the IP has been sold to Gearbox, but I would love to see the return of printers ala RoR2, a slight increase in base jump height for characters lacking mobility and some enforcer buffs. Love the character, but he needs some help.

[b] TLDR: It's one of the greatest roguelites ever and is a must - play for fans of the genre. The initial learning curve can be somewhat daunting, but its absolutely worth pushing through. [/b]

A pixelated side-scroller with the most challenging mechanics I've ever encountered. It's a remake and remaster of an earlier game, from which it borrows its title. Choose your guy, kill stuff on the screen as fast as you can (or deal with the consequences), and do it all over again.

Roguelike, with little progression between deaths other than unlockable items to drop for future runs. It has a 'mini-game room' reminding me of Super Smash Bros. where, if you complete a challenge or a game with special rules, you can unlock an alternate move or skin, which is a pretty sweet idea.

The screen can get ridiculously chaotic during the late game, so you have to know your characters well to have a chance to figure out just what in the world is going on. Every character feels extremely unique; not two are even remotely alike, and characters can switch 3 out of their four abilities at the beginning for even more variety.

A worthy remake of the original Risk of Rain. I still fucking despise the nerf to infusion that makes it garbage, but at least most of the new items are pretty cool. That said, more items means more bloat when you're playing without Command, which can make some runs somewhat questionable. 

The new Providence Trials are fun since the ones that unlock abilities also have other ways to unlock em. Most of them are pretty fun, but by god some suck so hard. Also, the final Trial can go die in a ditch. It's the most unbalanced thing I've seen. If you're gonna limit items, negate healing and force 8 stages in a row at least tweak the bloody items for the characters, some chars like Miner and Artificer are hell to play in this mode since you can barely stack enough to make them work. 

I've got a few other qualms too. Since they were revisiting the game they could've tweaked monster health and player damage. Much as I might love the game I CANNOT play it without having Glass on. I'll take dying in one hit for killing enemies at a decent speed any time of the day. Sure, it's playable without that artifact, but mate, I don't wanna be sitting there for 10 minutes the first few stages till I get some proper damage. 

Besides that, I don't mind the new enemies, but most are just mediocre at best. I hate the jumping balls and the birds with a passion tho, adding more aerials to a game with no means to deal with em is..... Sure, they eventually land, but screw waiting for that. Add lemurians and children now being able to climb ropes and shit just got a lot more annoying. 

Oh well, I've clocked 140 hours in a month and 100%'d it. I had fun and will continue having fun. For slightly over a tenner this is more than worth it.

Risk of Rain Returns is a fantastic remaster. For fans of the original, there are plenty of new additions to sink your teeth into.

We got new survivors, items, map variants, alternate skins, alternative abilities, artifacts, challenges, and secrets galore!  And on top of it all, the sprite art has gotten overhauled and looks gorgeous. (Also... you can play multiplayer through steam now.)

What's even better is that with all of the changes they've made, you have the option to turn them all off if you're a purist! Don't like the new maps or enemies? Get rid of them! Don't like how the teleporter works like in RoR2? Toggle it off! Is the game still too hard or easy for you on any given difficulty? Scale your damage taken/dealt up or down to your heart's content! This game has it all.

Going into a more serious section, Risk of Rain Returns is a fun remake of the first game, adding new changes to make it easier to get into for newer players familiar with Risk of Rain 2. At its core, RoRR is a 2D platformer with horde combat, and need for precision. Whether you are the hyper-mobile Digger with 2 dashes, in-built double jump, and 50 i-frames on average, or the bulky and immobile enforcer with no base-skills to shift you place to place, understanding the basics of the movement system will make a mountain of difference in survival.

Aside from that, another big difference is the impact that items have on runs. Sure, in RoR2 an ATG or Ukelele is nice, but often, character skills carry a major part of horde clearing, but in RoRR, a single ATG heavily impacts how much pain you'll be in. That is to say, items are a lot stronger, and tend to be what reduces the bite of the pain in this game. Granted, you can still die within a mistake or two, items are unable to be a crutch.

I love risk of rain, and have enjoyed the game so far, but I want to highlight a fundamental issue that can hopefully be addressed in future updates.

Currently, the game is extremely difficult in single player, but not in a good way. The difficulty stems from the fact that the maps are too large. Given that a main mechanic of the game is to optimize the tradeoffs between time (difficulty), collecting gold, and collecting items from chests, the size of the map makes this far too tedious as a single player. It can take several minutes to simply traverse the map and find the teleporter, and after clearing the boss, you need to then traverse back across the map to collect items, then traverse all the way back to the teleporter. This also doesn't factor in the times where you don't find the teleporter on your first traversal.. Was it back at your spawn? Did you miss it on a cliff somewhere? Better check the entire map again.

I'm not sure why I never hit this problem so hard in the first game. I'm not sure if there is a difference in the map size, character move speed, teleporter location, or density of items, but I find myself spending 75% of the game just.. walking across the map. I've also never found myself short on gold for items -- you almost always want to hit the teleporter immediately, because there is no way there will be enough items for you to spend all your gold. This removes one of those tradeoffs, where sometimes you would hold off on hitting the teleporter to collect more gold. 

I think, fundamentally, I would like to spend more time fighting enemies and collecting items, and less time walking all the way across the map to get a barbed wire. I'm not sure if this could be achieved with out-of-combat move speed, smaller maps based on the # of players, allowing the teleporter to be activated after the 90s from anywhere, etc. But, currently, it feels awful to have to restart a run because you spent 6+ mins on the difficulty timer just looking for the teleporter.

Risking Rain.

DISCLAIMER: I did not play the original risk of rain but I did play risk of rain 2. also at review time I had only played 3-4 hours, so this information is only a first glance at the game. 

Originally, I played risk of rain 2, and I thoroughly enjoyed it. 
when I saw they were remaking the original game I just got the game soon after release, during the festival of gup sale. here are my thoughts. 

The main difference between the two games is that one is 3d, one 2d. the switch between perspectives is not particularly jarring, the same strategies that are used in one, can be used in the other, with the slight change that returns is not as focused on using movement to survive as items, and certain movement focused skills are not as good in returns as they are in 2, such as the huntress' blink, which is only good to avoid enemy attacks, unlike in 2, where it was a long-range movement skill. 

I did enjoy my first couple of runs as there was not too much difference between returns and 2. my first run to complete the game with was with huntress, and I enjoyed the levels, which were much bigger than in 2, owing to an entire dimension being removed. I worked my way methodically through the bosses and enemies, getting reasonably good luck on item drops, until I reached the temple of elders and could go to the contact light and fight providence, the end boss. the only level I found annoying was the contact light itself. there are large blast doors which are required to go through, and you have to wait ages for them to open. several sections of the ship are locked by keycard doors, and the keycard item required to open them is a rare drop from enemies. the keycard doors are not required to fight the final boss, but almost all the item chests are behind them. 
Providence himself is actually a pretty fun boss, in comparison to his counterpart, mithrix. while Providence uses graceful and predictable attacks, mithrix flails around like an idiot, but somehow does more damage. while Providence uses giant worms that fill up the screen to attack you, Mithrix just spawns surrogates that die to a toothpick. In general I would say that returns does the end boss better than 2, as Providence is fairer and more fun than mithrix. 

The characters have not changed much. I only played 4 characters, so this may not follow for the rest. commando is slightly better in returns than 2, but is still a poor character that is designed to teach you the basics. Huntress is good as always but requires a slightly different playstyle of using your secondary and utility skill more, and relying on your movement skill less. Bandit is much worse, with his shotgun being nerfed into oblivion, he relies on his alternate skill, the whip, to be at least moderately effective. the loader is still decent, but not to the level she was in 2, as the really powerful charged punch is missing, and the scrap barrier, which means that hitting enemies gives you a shield, is replaced with a secondary attack which makes you momentarily invincible. the loader's grapple is slightly worse also, as it is had to control and not the overpowered traversal tool it is in 2. the loader's problems pain me as she was my Favorited character to play in risk of rain 2. 
Later edit: I have tried one of the new characters, the Pilot, and I think that it is my new favourite. 
The playstyle for the pilot is pretty complex, but still fun to use. all the attacks switch function depending on whether you are on the ground or in the air, and this creates an interesting character that requires strategy, skill, and a good deal of button mashing to get through. I would recommend this character as I have not seen anything like it in the previous game. 

The providence trials are an interesting new addition for the remake, as previously you needed to complete almost random tasks to get new items and abilities, and you still can do that, but the providence trials let you do it in a quicker way by doing trials of skill and strategy to unlock abilities and some items. the majority of items are still unlocked the old way, and all abilities can be unlocked the old way too, it is just more difficult. 

In general I would say that risk of rain returns is a good remake, and a amazing addition to the risk of rain series, adding new and old things in a more modern way. Highly recommend to anyone unsure as to rougelikes, as risk of rain is a good introduction to the Genre. I would also recommend it to anyone who played and liked risk of rain 2 or risk of rain 1. In fact I would recommend this game to almost anyone. 

I may update this review in the future but maybe not. 
for now, I would rate this game 10/10.

I've played this game for a while now and basically unlocked everything, and I would recommend this game. It has fun and creative combat, interesting items and characters, and difficult enemies and bosses. Everything is polished to a sheen, and the game looks and sounds amazing. The game has some very obvious flaws though.

TLDR: Buy if you love platformers and rouge-likes, but don't expect many QOL things from ROR1 mods or ROR2. :)

--- 1. Stage progression is painfully slow. The large stages, slow base move speed, and low density of items makes the game feel very slow paced at times. I've lost most of my runs to not being able to find the teleporter quickly and enemies becoming too hard to kill. This can be slightly fixed by zooming the game all the way out, but then things can become very hard to see. A minimap would help this issue. There is also no way to shorten the teleporter charge time. It will always be 90 seconds no matter how powerful you are.

--- 2. Bad items feel terrible to get. While many of the items in this game are good, some of them are basically useless (headstompers and bungus comes to mind). This is also the case in ROR2, but that problem is hugely mitigated by the existence of scrappers. This makes any item you get good, as you can change them into better items. Scrappers are not in this game, and as such, bad items are just bad. There are also no extremely good items that will save your run. (Except for Prophet's Cape, lol) This is compounded by my last point, spending 1-2 minutes to open a chest only to get a terrible item makes the game more RNG based then it should be.

--- 3. Lack of information. It can be very hard to tell what an item or ability actually does because the in-game descriptions are comically bad. Some items have very vague descriptions, some just have flavor text, and none show any numbers to let you know exactly what it does. This is a problem in many rouge-likes, but is even more baffling here because full item descriptions are already in the game! In the logbook, you get full descriptions of every item. Also, this game focuses on stacking items, and picking up an item a second time may have a different effect than picking it up the first time. Prophet's Cape, for example, heals you more when stacking, instead of shortening the cool-down on the block, like you would expect. (Not so say it should stack like that, I just what to be told how it works when I pick it up.) There is also no information on HOW items stack. I can guess that crit glasses stack linearly, and that the hermit's scarf stacks logarithmically, but there is nothing telling me this. (Though I recognize that this is very nerdy and most people don't care.) There is also no in-game stats menu. You cannot look and see your base damage, how much armor you have, your current attack speed, or anything for that matter. All of these issues can be solved extremely easily, the amount of mods for different rouge-likes that do it, even ROR1 and ROR2, shows this.

--- 4. Some unlockables are very dumb. For the most part, the Providence Trials are very fun. Many of them work as a tutorial on how to use the thing you are unlocking, and are challenging yet fair. However, some of them are terrible. (The Han-D bridge cleaning one is really truly terrible.) Some of the other achievements are pretty tedious too. (I hope I never have to drown another whorl.) But this is all pretty minor when compared to the other issues.

All in all, this is a great game, but it is dragged down by a collection of easy to solve issues that somehow made it past QA. Hopefully these issues can be solved in future patches. (they are adding horizontal aiming based on feedback, so there is hope) I've also heard rumors of workshop support, which would instantly solve all of these issues.

A phenomenal return to the original game, it seamlessly captures the feeling of the original while adding quality-of-life improvements and visual improvements. A cool feature is the option to toggle the original game's settings, like the requirement to kill all enemies before progressingâan homage to its unforgiving original design. Also the introduction of character challenges added a dynamic and innovative layer to the experience, featuring meticulously designed stages with puzzle-like gameplay.

What was especially interesting to me was the participation of Chris Christodoulou, revisiting some of his earlier compositions from Risk of Rain 1. This especially resonates for me, as I've loved those tracks since 2013âmaking it truly surreal to witness their continued impact on the game's evolution.

[i] Review changed from negative to positive [/i]  
  
Nvm I just be talking shit the game is very fun. There's still stuff that bothers me, but I guess I should write a review that's gona help people who are unsure if they want to buy the game.  
  
[b] If you haven't played the original RoR [/b]
I recommend reading the negative reviews that talk about the original game. You'll get a good idea about the "failures" of the first game and why people are disappointed. Once you understand "the bad side" of the original try and asses whether those are a deal breaker for you or something you can gloss over/manage.  
From personal experience: the game becomes A LOT more fun when you get better at it. It's flaws start looking like quirks or something you don't notice anymore.  
  
[b] If you've played the original RoR [/b]  
It's veery similar to the original. Has  more content and looks more pretty, Biggest change for me is the ability to move while shooting. Everyone can kite now, but you move slowly while doing it. Right now you can't change the direction of shooting while kiting (except huntress) which feels pretty clunky and bad, but you get used to it. They've announced earlier they're gonna "fix" this in an update that adds more aiming options so eagerly waiting for that.
  
  
Providence trials range from extremely fun to extremely frustrating, but overall they're not too difficult.  
Waiting for the artificer buff and for some alt abilities to feel more like sidegrades rather than obvious downgrades. Ropes are buggy, but it's a problem on just one map.  
  
There's plenty of secrets to find/unlock (characters, skins, areas, bosses, artifacts etc.)  
Most of my playtime is unlocking stuff by clearing achievements which was pretty enjoyable. You can modify how much damage you deal and take from enemies. This along with [spoiler] Command [/spoiler] make some horrible achievements turn into a breeze. Overall, unlocking stuff is easy and fun in this game. Multiplayer with randos was a nice pastime as well.

Ten years after Risk of Rain originally came out, and three years after Risk of Rain 2 actually fixed this problem, it's utterly inexplicable that they STILL haven't changed that the same button that progresses you from stage 1 to 5 then loops you instead of progressing you to stage 6. I'm tired of losing runs to accidentally looping, so this negative review stays until they swap the buttons or add a prompt or switch to the RoR2 system or SOMETHING.

Absolutely superb remaster of the original game. The music is great, the loop is fun, and the artwork is gorgeous; definitely pick it up if you were a fan of the first game.

Visually, everything has taken several steps up, the sprites, the effects, the animations, everything. Soundwise, I don't even have to say that the music is once again amazing, that should be understood already.

My main gripes are pretty few. The challenges, as so many others have already said-they need tweaking! The feel of attempting to climb ropes/ladders, as well as attempting to shoot while leaping off them or leaping between them feels....odd. Weirdly sticky but at the same time oddly inconsistent as to when I'll fly off or remain attached, not helped along by the fact that you can't jump to quickly dismount a ladder downwards (or to climb faster) while within terrain, though I can't recall if that was in the original or not. The artificer.....she needs a big rework, they've absolutely massacred her in attempting to keep her RoR2 kit in 2D-and they didnt even MANAGE that. The overloading worm seems to need at least some optimization, as it's reliably ending runs with Prowess, or just long enough ones that the game locks up from particles (the ONLY instance so far that I've seen, unlike the original game where getting three daggers could brick you)-amazing work on that end. And finally, the enemies' damage seems a little overtuned on default settings, but I suppose that's what the adjustable sliders are for. They also seem to scale up a lot faster than the original.

All in all, amazing game, and hopefully it'll receive the little bits of polish over the course of it's updates that will truly elevate it into a gem.

I can't recommend this game enough. A retro-style side-scrolling roguelike where difficulty scales with time - either take time to collect items and get stronger, or try to push through to the bosses before getting overwhelmed.

RoR Returns is a HD remake of the original game, with some absolutely gorgeous sprites and a few modern tweaks on gameplay (most of which can be tweaked in options to be like the original if desired). My favourite addition are the providence trials - little one-off challenges using specific items or skills, which allow you to unlock new abilities and skins for your characters. Makes a great change of pace from the main game now and then, and getting new abilities on old characters can sometimes make a big change to the way they play.

When the original RoR came out, I was impressed for the size of the team behind it (and that it had started as a school project?) The controls were archaic, but worked just fine for the game, and the lore and music elevated the game to another level. While the sequel, Risk of Rain 2, got some well-deserved popularity (and is a great 1-4 person 3ps), the original had a certain style to it, and played just differently enough, that it was always in my mind.

If you liked the original this is a no-brainer, and for $20 I think it's worth it at full price even just to try out, though if you didn't like the original then don't expect a change here. Note that I don't have friends, so have not tried the multiplayer on this (but it stands well as a single player game).

I was a fan of risk of rain 1, and this is just that but better.

To specify what is better: I think the art is better. I think the game handles better. I think the UI has some special touches (for example, your healthbar shaking as if it were hit, when you are almost killed) that really just make the experience feel... nice. 

It also adds a kind of minigame mode called providence trials, which is honestly my favorite part of the new game. Every character has 3-5 challenges, and the challenges are all fairly diverse. Many of them challenge you to get as high of a score as you can, or complete a goal in as short a time as possible. They all have an unlock tied to a target score, with an optional 'golden' score which is much more difficult to get. What I love about these challenges is that so many of them take advantage of risk of rain's systems to create an interesting challenge. 

My favorite is Main Systems Offline, which severely cripples your character and starts you in a small room, and periodically you get a key, which allows you to open more rooms and get items which make you stronger and allow you to access other areas. This is such an interesting take on the item system, it's almost like a very short metroidvania which is survival based rather than having you reach an 'end' point. I'd love to see games expand on this concept, but I'm not sure that'll happen, as this mode uniquely utilized the systems from this game. Maybe when they add mods, people will be able to make their own trials, and expand on this concept.

[h1]100% Achievement Review[/h1]

[h2]A must-have if you enjoy Rogue-Likes![/h2]

I came from Risk of Rain 2, having logged an absurd amount of hours into that game. I've also never played the original numero uno. This game has now become my favorite of the series. The graphic redesign is amazing, and the accompanying soundtrack has some new classics to add to your library. There's so much to unlock (I've even still got a few log entries to go), and the new Providence Trials add some intense challenges with mostly good rewards. Runs in this game compared to RoR2 are noticeably more difficult, especially on Monsoon. The RNG can really affect your run this time around, where I felt in RoR2 you can make just about anything work. The new characters are diverse in play style so I'm sure you'll find a survivor you will like to play. Runs with friends are enjoyable, but I feel are a tad more difficult than it should be with the lack of items being very noticeable. There's also a nice option to enable if you've got some greedy friends who don't like to share items. The logbook adds a lot of lore to the series which was something I greatly enjoyed about RoR2 as well.

[h3]Should you 100% the game?[/h3]

You absolutely [b]SHOULD[/b] unlock every item! There are some really powerful ones that will greatly increase the success of your runs.

You don't [b]NEED[/b] to unlock all the alternate moves, but some are vastly superior to the originals depending on the survivor. *ahemCyclone* Excuse me.

You don't need to [b]GOLD RANK[/b] all the Providence Trials. No extra content, no secret achievements (You do need 15 though for one achievement though). Just bragging rights! If you'd like some assistance getting Gold Rank, please check out my [url=https://www.youtube.com/SE4LS]YouTube Channel[/url] as I am making a video for each trial with tips for success.

Thanks for checking out my review. You should definitely add this to your Library :3

If you haven't picked up Risk of Rain all this time, the rock you live under must be pretty cozy. This title is one of the best roguelike arcade shooters of its time. An addictive gameplay loop packed with a cool pixel artstyle with and an equally awesome soundtrack. I daresay, the original title is way better than its 3D Sequel. 

Risk of Rain Returns refreshes this gem with more Survivors, more Mobs, and more silly-ass gear you can horde to your heart's content. 

Survivors come in a fresh coat of much detailed pixels, different color skins on the get-go but most importantly unlock-able alternate skills. These change up how each survivor plays out, and you can choose the skills that fit your play-style. 

There are new mobs and more elite variants that will hinder your progress -- the more you take your sweet time, the harder the punishment. 

And of course the ever-reliable equipment system is there with some fresh pieces that make each run unique from the last. 

The randomly generated stages are still there but packed with secrets to discover and collect -- one such aspect would be the artifacts which provide additional conditions to the run when you enable them. 

Last but not the least, the runs can be tailor-fitted to your play-style. Classic and Modern rule sets are available for your to tweak each time you deploy. A slider for Damage Dealing and Damage taken is also available on top of the hilarious difficulty settings. Dial it up or down based on your skills or lack thereof. And if ever running the gauntlet on end becomes boring, the game now boasts a Providence Trial mode that pit you against specific scenarios for a way to unlock certain alternative survivor skills, which are unlocked naturally through endless (frustrating) gameplay -- as if you don't have a taste for punishment. 

Overall, this refresh is a steal at its asking price, so get out from under that rock, and play under the rain.

Along with ROR2 this is one of the only roguelike games genuinely worth your time. There are a large variety of characters with very unique playstyles, there is even variety within those characters with unlockable alt skills. There is a similarly impressively large quantity of items and game modifiers (artefacts which each need to be unlocked). Some of these can be obtained relatively quickly but many either require you to complete a specific objective or will naturally accumulate over time. These therefore combine to give you a great sense of progression over time, whilst not giving you any inherent advantages on subsequent runs. The artstyle and soundtrack are also absolutely fantastic. 

Gameplay itself is just as, if not more fun as the sequel; the time = difficulty mechanic keeps you constantly on your toes and keeping you from playing it too safe. Skill is definitely a big part of the game and while it may feel RNG heavy at first due to randomised items (though this can be changed with an artefact), you will learn how to play better and survive longer. The fact that shooting slows you down significantly may seem clunky at first but its definitely something you get used to and does keep things balanced. There are a large variety of stages, bosses and enemies to keep things interesting too.

Providence trials are a new addition and from my experience are very hit or miss. Some of them are great and make you learn new mechanics and test your ability to use them; the trial where you play as mercenary and parry 25 attacks in a row is initially difficult but each one is satisfying to pull off and mastering the timing feels great. However some feel more frustrating than anything. One of the most disappointing in my opinion was one where you, as mercenary, fight another mercenary AI, which is fun to learn. However half way through the game just throws a ton of enemies in, ruining the duel and just making it more frustrating for no reason, as if the developers thought it wasn't hard enough, and instead of improving the AI or introducing more interesting challenges such as environmental hazards, they just threw in some difficult enemies and called it a day. These trials are how you unlock alternate abilities for survivors but thankfully you can also get them by just using the corresponding survivor a lot, so you don't have to complete them if you don't want to. 

Its a great game. Great variety in almost every department and tons of customisability to suit the game to your liking. Just like the second game, this is one of the only roguelike games to ever really hold my attention, and I'd strongly recommend you play it even if these kinds of games usually aren't your thing. There's probably something here for you.

too hard. I watch as many guides as I can, i go as fast as I can, I learn as much as I can, and it always ends the same: the game decides to spawn every enemy to ever exist for no discernible reason, and I die. It doesn't help that you move at a snail's pace and usually only have 1 movement ability, while everything else is fast as fuck. Shooting slows you down, and you have to stop moving and turn around in order to shoot behind you.

I get that it's a remake of an older game, and that they didn't pull any punches. That doesn't mean this game doesn't make you feel helpless as you watch your super lucky 15 minute run on stage 4 go to waste because 4 elder lemurians, 2 imp overlords, and 3 elite clay men surround you the moment you activate teleporter.

Having not played the original ror, the game is good, but i think id rather just play risk of rain 2 most of the time. The music is great, the new characters and art are all amazing, but it is a much slower and more difficult game than ror2 (which some people might like). I only have a couple real complaints. Most survivors have very limited (if any) movement options which (in my opinion) just doesn't feel good when the levels are massive and take a long time to traverse, and movement items are few and far between. The providence trials for unlocking abilities is cool and there's a lot of creative challenges, but they range from being super easy to feeling impossible. And sure, there are alternate ways of unlocking the abilities, but its usually like kill 3000 enemies or something that's pretty uninteresting and takes a long time.
However, even with the few complaints i have, the game is still fun, especially with friends. I don't think its for everyone, but definitely worth playing. And from what comparisons to the original i've seen, this is a big upgrade in almost every aspect.

I would've liked to leave a neutral review on the game but that's not an option, so let me elaborate.

Risk of Rain Returns is the first game but with less clear visuals and with pre-installed mods/things you'd get from a DLC for it.

Several annoying things from the original are still present in this remake, such as:
Waiting minutes for enemies to spawn so you can buy equipment.
Enemies and bosses spawning in areas they can't attack you from.
Still no sort of map selection.
Only getting items that do not synergize at all with each other.
The game spamming too many enemies at once, leaving you unable to defeat the current wave before a new wave of new enemies spawn.
Some item descriptions are still completely useless without checking the wiki.
(Though, admittedly, some of these aren't as common as they were in the original.)

Some enemies' attack hitboxes extend far beyond what their animation would telegraph.

Your drones will sometimes get too close to your character, making it hard to see your exact position and your immediate surroundings if you have more than 3 or 4 of them. Which is quite a problem in a game where you're supposed to dodge projectiles and do platforming.

For some reason, different from all other survivors, The Drifter doesn't have auto-fire for their primary attack.
This will lead to the player often and repeatedly pressing the primary attack button to fight off enemies, which not only causes discomfort and pain to some people, but it is well known as the source of Repetitive Strain Injury. This is exacerbated by the short length and range of the attack in a game prone to spamming enemies at you.
There is no reason for this in a game where literally every other character allows for auto-fire.
The only explanations for this from the part of the developers is that they are either somehow unaware of what it feels like to play their game or simply do not care if they are causing injury to the people playing their game.

If you think "the first game but more" is enough to justify a purchase, go for it.
However, if you were expecting "the first game but [i]better[/i]", just play Risk of Rain 2.

Not only are the stages too big horizontally, but also vertically. I feel like a quarter of my time playing is just going up and down ropes. The stages are so large that if you don't play zoomed all the way out, you're basically trolling, and at that point your survivor is so tiny you can barely even see them let alone appreciate their design.

I don't quite understand why the difficulty scales with time, shouldn't it scale with what stage you're on? It doesn't hurt anybody if I want to take my time and play at my own pace. But instead I feel punished if I'm not constantly going through the next teleporter. I heard the devs are adding mouse aim in a later patch, but for right now, every survivor feels clunky to play except maybe huntress.

Returns is using the same engine as 1 with the same 60fps cap, so you won't be taking advantage of any high refresh rate displays. I wouldn't expect extra meta progression, but it would be nice if I had a reason to keep playing the game outside of trials. I understand the game is inexpensive, but so is risk of rain 2. At this point in time, risk of rain 2 is actually cheaper when it's on sale.

Risk of rain returns is faithful to the original, no doubt about it. But risk of rain 1 had so many issues that they just simply didn't do anything about. It seems like the devs decided on a remaster, when what we really needed was a remake. A fresh coat of paint and some new assets can only go so far. Hopefully risk of rain 2 is more fun because so far, I'm not impressed.

[h1] Risk Of Rain but better, I guess. Exactly 10 yeast later. [/h1]

Honestly, I don't get why people are comparing this game to RoR2 so much when it's just remake of the first game. Tons of new stuff added, and you even have an option to switch all the rules to classic if you are masochist (killing all enemies before activating teleport honestly was least favorite mechanic in original). Other people are talking about how remake is not fixing some finicky or not streamlined flaws of the first game, like maps that are maps layouts and the fact that you, oh boy, can be instakilled if you walk into the crowd of enemies, like RoR2 doesn't have such situation and nobody complains, when it would really just mean they would make different game or something like parallel sequel, idk. It's literally core of first game with new face and new stuff and ideas added on top, while couple rough edges being smoothed. Also a hack for those who didn't played first game and want to get mad advantage: 
[spoiler]move Zoom Scale slider in option to x1 and your eyes will literally open. But at same time it might be a bit harder on your eyes in general. Honestly this option is almost a cheating in game where decision on where to go is crucial because time plays a big role, lol.[/spoiler]

[h2] Good [/h2]

[list]
    [*]All the fun that was fun in first one is same here, every run can go rather absolutely fantastic or horribly bad (most of the time, lol). Looping back through levels still brings chaos to your screen. 
    [*]First game was beautiful in it simplicity, second game was beautiful in adaptation of it's style to a different medium, remake is just beautiful in adding details to what was working good.
    [*]Music is still, in my personal taste, better than the second. It's more raw, more "tangy", suits the style of the game better.
    [*]Movement and gameplay overall feels just a bit more dynamic and faster, but still just like the first game.
    [*]New stuff mostly is pretty good. New items and items from RoR2 freshen up the experience.
[/list]

[h2] Bad (kinda) [/h2]

[list]
    [*]If you don't like more raw and hardcore kind of rogue-likes or didn't liked first game, this might be not your cup of tea.
    [*]Just like first game it can feel a bit frustrating and unfair because of bad rng or you loosing your character in chaos of action, but it's nature of rogue-likes, it's not meant to always dominate the game, sometimes it kicks you in the gut.
    [*]Providence Trails is somewhere neutral, towards bad I'd say. For me, they just seems like they are not fun. It's almost like devs was testing the water to new games trying to encorporate existing stuff and give it some kind of puzzle/challenge twist, but most of them honestly feels like task you will do once to open stuff and never come back. In general not bad idea for unlocking stuff (especially considering they give you alternative to open it via other achievements if it's too hard for you), but half of them are not very fun or challenging, others kinda a bit too hardcore for what they giving to you.
[/list]

[h2] Conclusion [/h2]

It worth to get if you love first game and want renewed experience, or didn't tried the first one and want to give it a go, you are not skipping anything from original. If you don't like more raw, harder rogue-likes or wanted completely new part Risk Of Rain, this might be not for you.

Risk of Rain Returns is definitely the proper way to remaster a game.
It has what the original game had, plus a lot more new stuff. A nice feature of the game is that you can disable a lot of the new stuff if you want the OG experience. A lot of accessability options have been added, plus more options for changing damage taken/dealt values if you want a more chill run.

Providence Trials are a new feature added in Risk of Rain Returns. They are difficult challenges that unlock skins, items and alternative abilities for your characters. Something worth mentioning is that there are alternative ways of unlocking the alternative abilities through normal gameplay, in case the challenge is too hard or you don't wanna bother.

One thing I need to get off my chest is that the Providence Trials are all difficult, with some being frustratingly so. And if you want a Gold rating on challenges, the difficulty rating dial is turned to 11. I am not a fan of it. Some challenges I'll never beat and some I've beaten I'll definitely never get Gold on. A large amount of achievements are tied to beating all challenges to unlock a special challenge, so you who seek to 100% the game will probably suffer quite a bit. 

That's it. Overall positive, if you like the original game then the remaster is worth your time.

Awesome game. I really enjoyed the three dimensions in ROR2, but this is just as fun. I found myself playing with different characters than i did in ROR2 and the trials are like fun mini games. Despite how fun it may be it is still very challenging at some times and i am far from walking through monsoon difficulty.  Having the artifact of command is awesome because you can test out different builds and see what the ideal is for each character and your play style. The levels are hard to navigate sometimes but it really helps if you zoom out and get a second jump immediately. 

If you enjoyed any of the ROR games i think it is worth a shot, i did not enjoy the first one myself but found this one fun. One of my favorite games for sure now despite the fact that I despise side-scrolling 2-D games.

It's a better version of RoR, which for me was one of the best games of the last decade. Graphics are great, music is phenomenal as always and the gameplay loop is satisfying. 
A minor issue worth mentioning: some of the controls feel a bit janky. After a couple of hours I got used to it and cleared the game, but it definitely feels a bit "off". The developers have stated that in the upcoming patch they're going to fix this by adding extra options for aiming, so there's a good chance this minor issue will no longer be there within a short amount of time.

[SPOILER WARNING]

Let me start off by saying this is one of my favorite games of all time and I highly recommend this game to anyone who likes a challenge. I've been playing Risk of Rain since the first game came out in 2013. Each game was even more enjoyable then the last. When i saw this games trailer i was so excited to play and when it finally came out I grinded the game. At the time i'm writing this I have 100% the game and only need to finish the last trial with every character.

First off, the graphics are a lot better then the first game I enjoyed getting to look at each of the characters and enemies new sprites. Along with the new enemies and stages everything was great.

Finding all the new stuff, such as Robomando and Boar Beach, was so exciting. The new artifacts as well make the game more challenging, after unlocking the Artifact of Prestige i used it almost everyone, which crashed my game a lot. I enjoyed the Providence Trials, some of them were difficult but that made it even more fun.

One of my most favorite parts of playing was when I beat providence and he had one last phase, it was awesome to see that even old stuff got something new to it. Every aspect of the game was amazing and didn't find anything negative to right about, and I can't wait for the new Risk of Rain 2 DLC to come out.

Definitely a challenging game, but the unlocks actually feel like an achievement when acquired. Lot's of fun, worth the wait for sure!

a remaster that not only stays true to the original; but adds so many improvements and content that makes it immediately as the definitive version to play. 
the new sprites and animations are huge glow-up compared to the 8-bit style as theres more substance and weight behind every action.
QOL accessibility options and keybinding changes vastly help improve the flow of the game, especially when finally change your skill bindings unlike the original.

and thank god that you dont need to manually port forward to play co-op anymore. its now as simple as just clicking a tab and inviting friends directly in steam. up to 4 players which i dont think the original game supported that max amount of players.

Overall this remaster is the definitive way to play the 1st game and i highly recommend it to any roguelike fans and ror2 fans.

An improved version of the original game that's worth its price. 

However, you shouldn't expect this to be better than Risk of Rain 2 if you're coming in from that. This is very much a different game and chances are you may not enjoy it as much. Alongside that, there are some issues such as the chests spawning like 30 miles apart, causing you to feel like you're playing a walking simulator at times with nothing happening (mainly early-game but it's always boring). Though, I've heard that turning off the new map variants fixes this since apparently they are so damn big compared to the original ones for some reason. Another thing I'm not really a fan of is having to kite enemies for 20,000 years in Monsoon if I didn't happen to get good items (unless you use Chef baybeeee best character in the game). The fact of this game being 2D kinda kills the enjoyability of that since it can feel pretty BS at times. I don't really remember that being a problem in the original game so that's why I bring it up here. Despite my complaints, I STILL think this game is an improvement. The new damage dealt/taken stuff, for example, actually mitigates every aforementioned issue rather well.

When it comes to the side stuff, I thought the Providence Trials were meh. A few are good, most aren't anything impressive, and some of them are like the worst thing ever designed in the history of video games. I have no clue why they decided to get Satan on the design team for some of these, like the one where you need to shoot 10 targets as Huntress while climbing ropes and then if you want to crown it you need to get 40 more. Like why? Who the hell decided that? Or alternatively the one where you have to knock enemies off of the map with HAN-D. Why do you have like -8 HP in that one? AND they have the boss that surrounds you with walls. Once he spawns, you are pretty much flipping a coin to decide whether or not you win since it gets way too chaotic for you to manage anything. It's so fucked up.

I've gotten my money's worth from this game and don't really feel like playing it that much anymore when Risk of Rain 2 exists, but I'm sure that there will be a lot of people that'll be able to have fun with this for longer than I did. Even if you don't, you'll still get a good bit of hours in since the progression is fun to go through. Once that's up though, you'll probably just go back to playing Risk of Rain 2, which is fine. At the end of the day, I shouldn't reaaalllly complain about this game since they didn't even have to add everything that they did. All of the new items, enemies, bosses, characters, sprites, music, and more are fantastic; we should definitely be grateful this remake even exists. I just wish it came out a little better gameplay-wise.

The beautiful thing about Risk of Rain Returns, is that it isn't an ENTIRE upgrade from the original. The original still has quirks and merits itself, but with growing pains. This however is a COMPLETE set of eyecandy, apt updates from ROR2, and essentially a "Scholar of the First Sin" edition of ROR. Now, anyone who knows Scholar of the First Sin knows...that isn't entirely an upgrade.

Playing on Monsoon is GENUINELY a struggle to even beat the game. Play at your own risk.

9/10. ESPECIALLY for the price.

A rare example of a perfect remaster, Risk of Rain Returns lives up to the original and pushes the original concept even further. The game perfectly balances new additions (including some of Risk of Rain 2) and quality of life improvements with a freshly painted game with visual improvements across the board. In the many hours I've played the only thing I've had a complaint about is that items get lost in the action a little when your zoomed out, but that single complaint is outweighed by the hours upon hours of fun this game offers and the enjoyment returning fans and newcomers alike will get from the experience. If you liked RoR2 or RoR original, you will like this game. If you have never played the series before this is a brilliant place to start, and it never hurts to have some friends along for the ride. TL:DR; Would get killed by an Elite Swift again 10/10

I had a lot of fun despite outright hating the mentioned parts of this game, so if you have enough self control to simply not select the parts of the game you don't like you'll love this game. I don't, and I still like the game.

What can I say that others haven't already? This is a remaster of one of the greatest roguelites every created. And they have improved on pretty much everything from the original game. The art is phenomenal. The original tracks have all be remastered and sound even better than they did before. The Providence trials are extremely fun and varied. They've added all new items that work wonderfully with all the preexisting items. 

The devs succeeded in in making some changes to the game, including adding a couple of classes and abilities while still keeping the vibe of the original game. Which I think was important because I really think Risk of Rain is a masterpiece. To change the vibe or make the game different in anyway from the original would have been a tragedy. This game is a 10/10 and absolutely should be in your library.

The stages are huge and barren and when you do find chest or shrines its extremely likely that youll get a useless equipment instead of anything remotely useful. You cant aim at all which is fine but the flying enemies are unable to be damaged by you most of them time unless you get lucky and have a hopoo feather or they fly low. Its fine to play for a little bit but it just doesnt have the flow or fun of 2.

Carried the original on a USB whenever I went when I was in highschool
RoR original was extremely hard and I'd say this one's just as much so you probably won't see your first win until about a dozen or so games in, but if you take your time to learn the way your character interacts with items, enemies and terrain, the game opens up in a wonderful way, especially now with all the added content.

Very good game, tons of fun to be had and absolutely worth your time especially if you enjoyed Risk of Rain 2. I should note that if you did play Risk of Rain 2 this game might be a bit hard to get used to as it has a different gameplay feel than the 2nd game. I don't mean that as in it being 2D, but rather how items are more spread out and how maps generally feel to play in compared to something like Risk of Rain 2. I did not like it at all myself when I started but after playing a lot and getting into the rhythm of the maps, I've come to enjoy them quite a lot, maybe even more than the Risk of Rain 2 maps. 

Small balance issues regarding enemy scaling as of writing this like 5 minute Blight enemies on Monsoon nearly one-shotting you or overloading enemies feeling much more difficult to get away from, at least compared to Risk of Rain 2, leading to some deaths feeling cheap. However, all of this just needs some minor tuning to be in a good state. Overall the game is absolutely worth your time, would absolutely reccomend.

I love Risk of Rain. NO matter what shape or form it's in!

Unless you're playing with a friend that can loot your items even when you stand directly on the chest dropping the item. 
I cannot begin to understand how he does it. The game doesn't have a "pick up item-button," but every single time I buy an item off a chest or something and it drops to my feet, he's there and he gets it.

Most people would think, well, that's simple. Just do the same thing to him, right? WELL! I can't! Every time he opens a chest and I stand right there beside him, he gets his own item, so... He gets both my items and his own items.

Would I want to be enraged over something like this again? Of course! 10/10 game! 
...but seriously, how the hell does he do it? TELL ME! 
Endgame boss? Who cares?! I have my "teammate" to work against!

I recommend this game but if your not a fan of platformers I wouldn't recommend this game to you also if you didn't enjoy the first Risk of Rain game, Returns might not be the best fit, as it maintains the core and style of its predecessor. It's a game designed for those who relish the fast-paced, constant movement inherent to the platformer genre, with expansive and vertically challenging stages

ReturnsÂ visuals and animations are commendable, preserving the same tone as the original but with higher definition sprites. The unlock system, which incorporates Providence trials, provides depth to growth by presenting players with distinct challenges and powers to unlock. Chris Christodoulou's music shines like usual, capturing the charm of the original while expanding

However, there are some serious problems. The levels are way too big, which causes annoyance and slowness when navigating them. The use of ropes can become tedious, and the lack of surrounding cues makes directions difficult. The secret places are also prone to shoddy design, which detracts from the overall delight of exploring. Traversing some of the maps are a nightmare. I feel like they could have added much more versatile ways to get around besides ropes and geysers. The mobility of characters isn't that great either the movement speed for most characters isn't that great compared to enemies.

Equipment are way too plentiful, Most of the time you get equipment almost every time on the first stage and probably never select another one again. From my experience almost every other chance shrine I get one. Not to mention bosses for some reason drop equipment. Shrine of mountains aren't as good as R2 because of this

Items are way too spread out which doesn't help with the strict difficulty scaling, it's hard to go through the entire map and collect all items when you are on Monsoon it's almost always better to just get what you can and hit teleporter early instead of spending additional time finding items that probably won't help you

In terms of combat flow, there's a lack of engagement since most of combat is facing a linear line of monsters and using all your skills just to wait and dodge everything just to do everything over again. This diminishes the strategic aspect and turns combat into a routine of using cooldowns, retreating, and waiting. I feel like with combat they should introduce more variety in enemy behaviors, potentially including more flying enemies or those that demand different tactics. This would create a more engaging combat experience, encouraging players to adapt their playstyle

by all means I still think this is a great game but I don't think it's good as Risk of Rain 2

I love this game.

This is hard to downvote as I love RoR and RoR2, but RoRR has one major problem its difficulty. Now I've seen posts that its got the same settings as RoR but I simply don't believe it. I could regularly get to Providence in RoR and with the remaster, seven hours in, I've not made it to the final level yet, let alone the final boss. 

Does it ruin the game? No, in fact there's alot to enjoy about the remaster not the least of which is a reminder about how damn good the original soundtrack was and is. I will continue to play this game. But I can't recommend it to people starting the series. This is clearly designed for returning expert vets who are wiling to tolerate enormous swings in difficulty thanks to the RNG rouglike gods. 

If you enjoyed RoR by all means put up RoRR. If you're looking to discover this wonderful series start with RoR2.

Having played a considerable amount of Risk of Rain 2, and never the original before this, I hated this game initially. The movement felt slow and clunky, the direction you can shoot being tied to the direction you're moving was annoying, and honestly it was just really damned hard. Then after a few runs and new unlocks of both characters and items, it grew on me. 

It is very different to Risk of Rain 2, so definitely don't come in expecting more of that. But it still has a lot of the same charm, just in a different format. And the soundtrack absolutely slaps, as usual.

This game is a jam start to finish, it's incredible how it achieves to feel very different from its predecessor, risk of rain 1. From updated sprites, to updated bangers from Chris Christodoulou, increased map variety, new items, survivors, alternative abilities, challenges and meaningful balance tweaks that fix the things Risk of Rain 1 might've lacked in. Risk of Rain Returns leaves me feeling optimistic about Risk of Rain as a whole, and hope that gearbox can continue to deliver on this beautiful franchise that Hopoo Games brought to life back in 2013.

Remake of the original Risk of Rain, updated for a more modern feel with some additional content. A great time for a happy fun-time massacre, open to more skill levels due to allowing you to choose the damage percentages dealt and received in addition to the difficulty. This can also be modified individually per player in multiplayer, opening it to groups with varying levels of skill.

Overall a very good game, though some of the unlocks can be a bit grindy / frustrating to unlock.

Great update to the original RoR. I've dropped at least a few hundred hours in both RoR 1 & 2, and this is an excellent refresh. That said... either I got old/bad, or there's something wonky going on with the difficulty scaling. It feels like you're severely punished for re-playing previous levels in your run. Suddenly dropping 5-6(!!) Scavenger bosses after 20 minutes of play on the LOWEST difficulty level is silly and painful. I get you're not trying to let players go infinite too easily, but c'mon, that's just anti-fun. Great game, just needs some tweaking over time, like all great games.

Risk of Rain: Returns is an absolute master-class in how to bait someone into playing hours of your game based on good game-feel alone. [h1]Turns out Risk of Rain 1 was good enough to warrant the release of Risk of Rain 1 2[/h1]

It is basically a remaster + expansion of RoR1, but in essence it's the same exact game. It is still a platformer at heart, if you didn't like the original chances are you won't like this one either.
Added more stage variants and stages are bigger. OST is a banger with remastered music and new songs.
The bestiary and log section is incredible, you can view the entire map of every stage variant, high quality pixel art for every enemy. The pixel art is simply gorgeous.

There are some bugs and the autoaim feels very wonky compared to the original (from my experience this is due to the added ability to move while shooting, and there is a confirmed fix coming), the movement on the other hand feels a bit better than the original.
The trials seem very fun and knowing Hoopoo I expect them to get very hard in the later stages. (Already read posts about people getting tilted over some of them lol)

Could use some more settings especially when it comes to UI, no non-V-sync frame lock option, no og/modern soundtrack options, unintuitive borderless option, no way to toggle enemy corpses, etc. Some bugs like being able to order lobbies by ascending ping yet the displayed ping is always 0, and minor text bugs.

Intensity alongside other tweakable features to customize your gameplay even further, which can be individual or shared in co-op lobbies. Talking about co-op, you have chroma skins and outlines. You can force item sharing so one player doesn't steal every item. Whenever you die in co-op you turn into a drone that can fly around and shoot until killed or TP'd to the next stage, during which you can still pick up items but not interact with objects. No ability to ping though.

It's weird seeing how some setting having so many options and some others having so few, and some of the inconsistencies. The font is still horrid but you can now toggle between that and a bigger more legible font, no scaling. It gets worse because when using the bigger font, some tooltips are cut short due to no 'overflow' setting for the text areas.

-[b]For the purists[/b], it includes a "Classic" setting it ends up playing like the original, alongside a custom one to disable whatever new feature you don't want to see.
-[b]For the RoR2 babies[/b], this is RoR1-2 bitch!!! we clown in this muthafucka betta take yo sensitive ass back to RoR2! (there is no free aim option at least as of yet, 2-directional aim only like in the original).

Overall and assuming most bugs are gonna be squashed and some things rebalanced, it's a huge upgrade from the original in every way, and no need to port-forward anymore to play online co-op. Certified banger. 
[h2]Holy shit there actually is rain 10/10 masterpiece[/h2]

It's effectively 90% the same game as the original down to the game feel before considering the visual facelift into proper pixel art and new content and balance tweaks, with very greasy Gearbox taking up 75% of the game credits for a meager fraction of the actual work.

Most of the new items entailed are essentially a curated backport of RoR2's actually useful ones, and Artificer is just as bad here as she was there; some things never change. The other new survivors are otherwise good, there's a 'that kid' unlock process, a few more artifacts hidden around, and there are some new stage variants to shake things up a little. But there's no actual 'new' stages proper, and the soundtrack is still mostly the same outside of a few cases. Still a fantastic one as ever, though it may create something of a juxtaposition with the game walking a blurred line between remaster and remake between the gameplay and visuals as-is.

Whether game balance is any much better is debatable; some survivors got notable tweaks, flying enemies are far stronger, chest distribution seems to be worse, some enemies now climb ropes, many of the less useful items are still bad, and while Infusion is actually balanced with Glass active so bad players can't cheese it for free damage, other changes make playing that artifact more annoying than challenging. Unmodified gameplay may still result in fighting rather spongy enemies. Percentile modifiers to damage given/taken though do provide a solid alternative but will realistically be abused by many to unlock content reliably.

The most notable new feature in Returns otherwise is a bunch of pre-made trials. They vary massively in difficulty and fun, rewarding more unlockable items but also notably as the method to get RoR2-style alternate skills. Sadly, many of them suffer the same problem, that by comparison to the original they're either a straight upgrade or so gimmicky, that they're basically designed around its trial.

Being able to use Steamworks to host and join games with ease than having to deal with any port forwarding is a good point worth noting over the original, but sadly it's limited to four players until modding finds a way around that. Dead players now also become drones and have an opportunity to collect dropped items if they survive in that form.

In the end, it's a fine re-release and it's still classic Risky with some welcome amenities here and there. But it also does have to compete with the selection of mods available for the original, including Starstorm - which one of the developers for Returns worked on originally.

Great job remaking the original Risk of Rain. The added characters and items are fun so far, and the game runs smoothly. I look forward to playing multiplayer with my friends again.

Has some benefits over Risk of Rain 2, namely that it no longer feels like you're either winning spectacularly or already dead, and the overall fidelity of the assets has obviously improved over the original Risk of Rain release, but there's not a whole lot past that I can say I like.

This franchise as a whole feels like what happens when you get a decent, engaging idea going, but the team developing it lacks experience. Every entry in it thus far has had several things I could point to bringing it down. It usually manages to be fun despite this, but the potential available is decidedly not being met.

In Risk of Rain 1, the primary let-down was the controls being bad, the maps being far too large, and mobility feeling about nonexistant. As far as a first game goes, however, this is highly forgiveable.

In Risk of Rain 2, the maps are [i]still[/i] too large, the terrain is very plain, and you will more often than not end up winning hard until something spontaneously one-taps you without you even knowing what it is. Not to mention a final boss that is entirely obnoxious to fight. Still, movement was a lot better, as was the aiming and controls generally.

But then we get here, to Risk of Rain Returns. The controls are still much better - I'll give it that. I'm still very annoyed I can't aim with the mouse properly, but that's coming in a future update, so I'll let it slide. But the rest of the problems are still here in force. Sure, you can move while shooting now, that's great, but you're still slower than molasses in January, so I still feel like a slug in tar. The maps are still immense and irritating to navigate, and both of these issues compound the difficulty unnecessarily.

But the thing I hate most about this release is the Providence Trials. I don't know what was going through the heads of those that made them, but the vast majority of them are ridiculously infuriating to complete. Difficulty out the nose, with several of them utilizing gimmicks that the game was very clearly not designed to handle. I [i]loathed[/i] them, and while you can ignore them for alternate skill unlocks (as other unlock methods are available), there are several items that can [i]only[/i] be obtained via them, and I find it obscene.

And yet honestly, despite this all, this review could've been a tentative positive one. Indeed, for a while, it [i]was.[/i] But the constant difficulty imbued in so many of the challenges in combination with the entirely unnecessary put-down lines thrown at you every time you lose is just barely enough to tip it over the edge into the negative, as I can't respect developers who feel the need to insult their own players.

Overall, Risk of Rain as a whole has been defined to me by its inherent possibility for greatness in combination with its consistent ability to disappoint and fall short of that promise. It's decent, and you'll probably have fun, but it [b]will[/b] be very rough around the edges.

Risk of rain returns is a f***ing awesome game that was entirely worth the 20-30 i spent on it, and I'mm going to tell you why.

The Characters:
You start with 2 characters, the commando and the huntress. there are 15 to unlock (along with [spoiler] [i]a certain someone[/i] [/spoiler]), and they are all good, fun and different.

The story:
No real story spoilers (figure it out yourself).
A cyclops by the name of providence is pissed that the contact light (the ship your on) is passing through petrichor v, and also annoyed because someone managed to take a teleporter from the planet and put it on the contact light. he decided to go and commit task manager against the ship, killing essentially all of its crew except for 15 characters [spoiler] and a funny looking robot [/spoiler]. your dropped onto the planet with nothing except what you could grab on your way out, and anything in those chests that are raining from the sky.

The gameplay loop:
This IS a rougelike, so its a gameplay loop instead of following a story
You drop onto the planet and need to immideitly commit mass genocide, because the locals aren't too happy about you encroaching on their land, and will do everything in there power to stop you. but for some reason, they are MADE of money. kill some, and open the money locked chests to gain new items to keep up with the ever increasing threat of the timer which makes enemies stronger that father into a run you go. oh, and worry, they WILL outscale you, so you need to be fast and keep ontop of the hoards. Once you reach stage 5 you are given a choice, go to the contact light and make your escape, or return back to that first stage to continue the run and go through all the stages all over again. if you choose this path, I have some good news: every stage including and after stage 5 contains a more powerful teleporter, which is capable of letting you continue the run or letting you go to the contact light whenever you please, so long as your still alive. IF you are still alive of course, as after that first tele loop, monsters start to scale much more rapidly, doing way more damage and becoming way tankier and you will be seeing a lot more elites. when you decided to go to the contact light, the goal is no longer to find the tele. the goal is to instead reach the front of the ship, so that you may go ahead and kick providence's kneecaps in. Providence himself is no joke however, as he's capable of demolishing your healthbar in an instant if you are too stressed to dodge. thankfully, he has tells, and even with literally no movement items or ability's, with enough skill, EVERYTHING can be dodged (he's actually a really cool boss, but he's not extremely hard. I do wish he had more attack pattern variety but its fine). Once he's dead your allowed to leave and win the run.

Meta progression:
This game has over 150 different total unlocks, from items, to survivors, to skins, and all the way to unique abilities for everyone, no stone goes unturned. However, some challenges are VERY hard, so you better be prepped to have your ass handed to you on a silver platter.

Music:
Chris don't miss.
the tracks for this game are some of the best I've heard, managing to rival legends such as the bop of the jetpack joyride theme, pizza tower soundtrack, ultrakill soundtrack, and payday 2 soundtrack. that's how good it is.

All in all the game is AWESOME and you should ABSOLUTLY buy it without question. it will be tough but you'll figure it out. go and kick providence's ass, for all of us.

Risk of Rain Returns is an extremely solid remake: it's very fundamentally unchanged from the original, but it's a big improvement in terms of graphics and adds heaps of content that makes the experience more enjoyable and adds additional replayability to a game that was already extremely replayable. The new characters are interesting and fun, the Providence Trials are really cool and a lovely addon to the main game, the new and returning mechanics add some more fun options, and the new items are delightful. To a certain extent I wish they would've added new stages as well, but I understand why they wouldn't given the effort they put towards tripling the layout options for the stages that were already there, and also giving each stage has a bunch of secrets to find spread throughout it's variations. Being able to play as a drone where you can still participate by shooting and picking up items after you die is a massive improvement to the multiplayer of the game, and I very much hope it's a feature added to Risk of Rain 2.

It's a fantastic remake of what was already one of my favorite games, and it's well worth the price.
