A beefed up version of the original Risk of Rain, with new modes of play, challenges, characters, abilities,  items, environment layouts and more.

Some of the "new" characters are from RoR2, and some are completely new. Characters now have alternate ability choices much like RoR2. Some abilities have multiple ways to unlock them which gives accessibility for players who don't want to interact with the Providence Trials game mode.

When the original game launched, setting up multiplayer was a pain with having to get a Hamachi server up and running. Thankfully in RoRR multiplayer is as easy as creating a lobby and inviting or joining from the Steam friends list.

Many art improvements have been made, and the soundtrack is as great as it ever was with some additional  songs added in.

I had over 100 hours in the original game, and I can see myself getting even more than that out of Returns.
If you're at all familiar with the original, RoRR will feel right at home with you with enough additional content added to keep the experience feeling fresh.

This is a good remake of the original Risk of Rain! The new items are interesting, the reworked sprites look gorgeous, the music is as banging as it was when the game originally came out in 2013. All bugs that were in the first game have been fixed as well. All in all a pretty good game.

â HOWEVER â 
To me it is [i]just[/i] that: A remake. This means the game adapted all the flaws I saw with the original as well. The main one being that the player can only shoot in 2 directions, left and right. Because of that, to me, most runs feel like I'm just spamming all my attacks when they are up and keep rapidly jumping through the stages while running away from enemies as to not get hit as often. 

I feel like the devs had the chance to reinvent their first game by letting players shoot in all directions, giving them more verticality. Generally making the gameplay more interesting and fast paced like in Risk of Rain 2. They did not take that chance.

This is an excellent remake of the original Risk of Rain that I can't stop playing. The original Risk of Rain had a lot of rough edges that often made me hesitant to play it that have been smoothed off, polished or enhanced in the remake. What stands out to me is how much better the movement feels. This is in part because there are more movement options, but also because the enhanced animation all of the survivors got sells their speed so much better and as a whole is one of my favorite things about the remake. There's so much more to talk about, like how much more generous the unlock system is, how much nicer the entire game looks, how there is built in multiplayer that doesn't require 3rd party software that was probably spyware and how the difficult is much more malleable to be more or less punishing. It's excellent.

But mainly it's that survivors actually look like they are climbing the ropes now instead of the weird humping animation they had before. 10/10

I'm a fan of the Risk of Rain series.

It's a great game - there's plenty of reviews explaining why, whether you're a RoR veteran or a newcomer action roguelike enjoyer. But I will add that it's a perfect Steam Deck/handheld game.

Like the original - and unlike the 2nd game - it's side-scrolling, aim left and right, so controller controls are perfect for it (I just swapped the triggers as it feels more natural to have primary attack on RT). And I've been playing on my Asus ROG Ally while travelling, and even in silent mode (10W) in later stages when it's chaos on-screen it's a rock solid 60 FPS.

So if you're in need of a good travel game or something while laying in bed at night to wind down, definitely give this one a go.
It's a breath of fresh air, it is still hard to get used to aim, but i have a bunch of fun with it.

After a bit of playtime and finally 100%ing the game, I now feel I can leave a review.
I wont leave a negative review like the other people because while I do have a couple of issues with the game, overall this game is great and I have had fun my entire time playing this game and the issues this game has I am very confident they will be addressed in future updates, just like in risk of rain 2.
I have two main issues with the game right now(and no I will not mention trials cause I personally enjoyed most of them) character balance and difficulty.
[h1]Character Balance[/h1] 
Now, while most of the characters feel fine to play there are quite a few of them that are a little....odd.
The main, and arguably worst, character I want to talk about is the artificer. I feel like I kind of understood what they were trying to do with this character, but what it boils down to is a very gimmicky and frustrating character to play as. Like you are supposed to kite the enemies around into a large group, block them off with ice wall, then use the abilities to mow them down with your "high burst and DoT". What actually happens is you kite around for 15 seconds with no mobility, to get all your cooldowns back, pop an ice wall, charge for 10 seconds and shoot your secondary in the wrong direction, and then use your flamer that's not sure if it wants to DPS or DoT while half the pack of mobs ignores the ice wall and mauls you down before you have time to do damage or cancel, all this to be less effective than most other character's LMB.
The other cast members that I have gripes with (acrid, sniper, bandit) are....fine, but I feel they could use some tweaks and they are the characters that I feel are also super gimmicky, but unlike artificer their gimmicks actually work for them.
The main character issues I have are with the character alternate abilities. Like....WTF are these? 70% of the alternate skills are straight up just bad. Like the teleport arrow for huntress, basically every single secondary skill for artificer (no surprise there), the drifter scrap cube, etc. Like all of these abilities felt like they were made for the providence trial puzzles alone and nothing else. Some of these abilities need like major balance changes or just be reworked entirely cause it feels like there is no point in wasting time in the trials/grinding the character getting these.
[h1]Difficulty[/h1]
Now before I continue I want to say I will put this section into two separate reasons that I believe is the cause of the seemingly high difficulty. Enemy scaling and item-to-enemy ratio.
So in the official risk of rain discord (shout out to the amazing dev team) they themselves confirmed to make the game feel a little more fair and less of a steamroll on our side is they scaled the enemy health and damage up so it wont end up as a giant one-shot fest. While Im all for this I feel this was a little over-tuned on their part as in levels, especially once you get to Stage 3 or so and once you get past the first loop then....well good luck from there. I personally play with damage taken at 75% as that makes it feel a little more like the original game, which is how I have fun.
The second issue is the item-to-enemy ratio. When playing through the game and grinding all the achievements, artifacts, items, etc. It became increasingly clear that there was a large gap between the amount of items you got in a stage and the sheer amount of enemies spawning at once. But it makes sense for solo, what about co-op? its just as bad there as the amount of chests feels almost the same as when playing solo and makes for a worse experience as it feels like you are fighting for items at time. I have had multiple runs where I load into a stage and NOT A SINGLE chest spawns in the entire area (IDK if its a bug with this, but I did report it to the risk of rain team and we'll see where it goes). So with very little items and enemies that can pile on and ramp up in damage and health it can make the game seem way more difficult than it actually is.
So for anybody reading this review, while these are issues with the game I can 100% recommend picking up this game and giving it a try. Don't let the doomers fool you into thinking this is an unpolished game. All the issues with this game are mostly addressed and will be fixed by hopoo.

It's [i]Risk of Rain[/i], but polished up with higher resolution, more detailed art, new content, and nice quality-of-life features like multiplayer without the requirement to do port forwarding. If you enjoyed the original, you'll love this, and I think it's well worth the price. If you didn't enjoy the original, though, then you probably won't like the remaster either.

If you're a [i]Risk of Rain 2[/i] player who missed the original, I'm not really sure if you'd like this remaster. It's certainly worth a try, though. Worst case, if you find you're not enjoying it after a couple runs, you can refund it.

It's a tough ass nails 2d roguelike. It's different enough from Risk of Rain 2 that you won't automatically like it if you like Risk of Rain 2, but it is a good game.

Just as the original did 10 years ago, this game has captivated me and quickly sucked up a lot of my free time. All the refinements make this feel much more solid, and the new artwork is wonderful. Most of the new content is great, so if you liked the original I see little reason you would not like this. There is a lot more to unlock this time too, so that should keep completionists decently busy.

However, I do find the Providence Trials largely tedious and not enjoyable in the slightest... which makes the fact that some items and an artifact are unlocked solely through doing them even more exhausting. Locking certain skins behind the final trial is fair though. Furthermore, I do find a couple of the new enemies to be very annoying to fight, namely the Macrobe. There are other little issues I have here and there, but nothing that ruins the overall experience. Archer bugs and overloading magma worms still exist anyway.

But all those transgressions can be forgiven because I can be a secret dolly and I can kill my parent to get anything for free in any store.

Risk of Rain Returns represents Hopoo Games' heartfelt farewell to the cherished Risk of Rain franchise, marking the transition as Gearbox takes the helm. This installment also elevates the experience by integrating quality of life enhancements from Risk of Rain 2 and enhancing the original's artwork. Introducing new control schemes, the game extends a welcoming hand to both newcomers and RoR2 players, offering a more familiar and engaging playstyle. Moreover, the addition of Chris Christodoulou's remastered soundtrack elevates the overall experience, enriching the game with its captivating music.

[h1] Faithful to the End [/h1]
Risk of Rain Returns is a faithful "remake" of the original Risk of Rain 1, bringing back the original mechanics, while adding in new refinement from Risk of Rain 2, with new characters, items, enemies, and more to boot.

[h1] More than a Remake [/h1]
Despite technically being a remake, I would honestly say Risk of Rain Returns is more than that - many remakes are characterized by refinement of mechanics from the original, such as in the RE4 or Dead Space remakes, with not too much new. However, Return is a step up from that, with numerous new mechanics to play around with [spoiler] and the cute little fella, Robomando! [/spoiler]

[h1] Difficulty Done Well [/h1]
Risk of Rain Returns is a fairly difficult game compared to many modern roguelikes/lites nowadays, Risk of Rain 2 included. However, this is a preservation of the original game's difficulty, and it's preserved practically perfectly while also maintaining the refinement of a remake - compared to the original game's more clunky and bullet sponge-y enemies, Return drops the bullet sponge in favor of a somewhat more advanced AI, as well as the gameplan-changing ability for enemies to climb ropes, a huge change for those who played the original.

So no everyone, Return is not more "difficult" than Risk of Rain 2 - rather, Risk of Rain 2 is just got easier. 

[h1] Polished Control [/h1]
While the controls and movement are not to everyone's preference, Return smooths out the clunkiness (and lack of mouse binding!) from the original, allowing for a better overall experience and more comfortable feel.

In addition, the tricks to avoid being stopped when attacking continue to exist as well - try jumping just before you attack! 

The accessibility options are also a welcome change, even if they might end up accidentally breaking some characters, such as the Autofire option allowing Loader to just attack at maximum primary speed as opposed to you needing to tap the button to get that fast.

[h1] Graphical Refinement [/h1]
That said, the mechanics aren't the only well-maintained aspect of the game - the graphics have received a large upgrade, with much more detailed and polished designs and sprites, especially with the new logbook format allowing for excellent portraits and stage viewing. 

Some may not like the pixel art, but this was the style of the original, and frankly, the pixel art is part of the charm of the game, especially with the overhauls.

[h1] A Worthwhile Play [/h1]
All in all, Risk of Rain Returns is a very faithful "remake" of the original Risk of Rain 1, giving us many quality of life improvements, as well as entirely new content, and is something I'd recommend to roguelike/lite enjoyers as a whole, and of course to dedicated Risk of Rain fans as well. Try it and get used to it - you won't regret it.

This is a very enjoyable rougelike for me, having never played risk of rain 1 I canât compare the two, but for $15 this game comes with more than enough content compared to other games priced at $15.

It takes 1 or 2 videos and lots of failed easy difficulty runs to figure out the flow of the game but once you get the tempo down the game becomes way more enjoyable.

There are lots of different characters to unlock, each with different playstyles but mainly between ranged or melee playstyles with smaller differences in each character.

As youâre playing throughout the game youâll complete different challenges to unlock new items that will appear in your runs. The game also gives you lots of different âminigameâ type challenges that are a fun break from the normal game and reward you with new items, moves, or cosmetics on completion. These minigames and challenges provide you with a nice feeling of permanent progression in a rougelike game.

The amount of customization and replayability in this game is major and if you enjoy playing it youâll be able to play for a long time before getting burnt out. Each run youâll get different items, levels, and bosses, youâll have to play differently and try your best to adapt. (Or sometimes you get screwed over by bad rng like any other rougelike)

Watch some gameplay videos on this before you get it. Itâs nothing like any other rougelike Iâve played and did take me some time to get into, but now that I know how to play properly Iâm enjoying it a lot.

The only thing I hate about this game are those stupid green bird enemies that crash into you. If they kill me again Iâm going to change this review to a negative one.

In your first few hours of gameplay, you might be inclined to think that this game is not worth your time. You will hate certain enemies. You will get mad at the bad items the game gives you. You might compare it with Risk of Rain 2 and say that this isn't even worth playing.

But trust me, it's [b]literally[/b] just a skill issue.

Soon you will get used to the controls and your character's abilities. You will learn how to deal with the enemies. And you will make use of every item you find. This game is extremely rewarding to master, while always keeping you on the edge of your seat.

And of course, this is way better than the original. The improvements in graphics and audio, the new characters and items; everything makes this better than plain old Risk of Rain.

In short, Risk of Rain Returns is [i]very[/i] good!

Perfect remaster of the original Risk Of Rain.
It retains everything from the original and even leaves you the choice to not use some of the new stuff if you'd rather have the entirely original experience. But whether it's the art, the items, the survivors, the music, the difficulty (etc.), they all feel perfectly on par with the original game and improvements were actual improvements, not stylistic choices changed for no reason that make it derive from the source (art style being a big one, everything looks better but still feels the same).
Unfortunately, that also means some of the more frustrating things of the original game came along, but just gotta get good I guess? (like a challenge for not getting hit for 3 stages being a little much, or the way controls work sometimes can be frustrating)

The new additions are also pretty nice and fun, the new survivors and items, as well as the Providence Trials. Trials seem more or less fair depending, but I managed to finish even the most frustrating ones and they're not mandatory (at least for most things, there are two achievements for getting 5 and 15 with gold).

And the biggest of all is probably just having a multiplayer that works. It looks heavily inspired by what they did in Risk Of Rain 2, but that's good because the experience is very simple and straightforward (when before it was just a pain and even when port forwarding things correctly didn't work sometimes).

I think overall it's just a wonderful improvement of the original Risk Of Rain, there's not much reason to get the original when this exists (especially since you can play it with all the new additions disabled if you wish). And after Risk Of Rain 2, it's nice to see they understand their roots (and learned from Risk Of Rain 2 rather than let it define what they are), instead of trying to make Risk Of Rain Returns into something different.

I really enjoyed the original version of this game when it came out; it was a challenge and one of the few bullet-hell platformers I ever enjoyed.  When the 2nd game came out I was caught by surprise and fell in love with the franchise.  Seeing the original remade and "Returning" with modern amenities and new content brought a smile to my face.  Don't be fooled though, this game is hard.  Harder than RoR2 and the original.  You will die, a lot.  But with time comes experience.  It was funny to hop into this game with my friend, only to see that the easter eggs and artifact spots of the first game were here in the 2nd as well.  I really was laughing when my friend found a "mega teleporter" on the frozen mountain level just for me to tell him its an artifact spawner where we gotta press some buttons around the map.  I didn't look that up, I remembered it from 10 years ago!  The blend of nostalgia and newness was done right with this one, so buy the game if you want tons of replayability and a hard game.

This game is riddled with many frustrating moments and generally tends to be montonous in its way of being "challenging" to the player and its all for the worse. They missed real hard with Artificer's primary (which is meant to be her main source of damage), the only way you can get away with using it is just with stuns and the ice wall, other than that, it isn't as snappy and high-damaging as her primary in Risk of Rain 2. I wish they gave her an alternate primary to mirror the ones she had in her previous game, which although were affected very little by attack speed increases, at least served their purpose as a consistent main source of damage. The new one is a wet noodle multi-hit attack that can't be used that consistently, so she generally feels one-note because you're just using nano bomb or flamethrower most of the time. as the damage output of the primary lacks so much impact. 
Another frustrating element has to do with how extreme the game makes its challenging aspects relative to how much the player can actually do to strategize or mitigate punishment. If there is an overloading enemy in a horde, there is no real way to single them out of the group, they will stay there and you just have to deal with getting your healthbar snapped in half constantly due to how frequent and high damage their absurd passive shock attacks are. Other challenging games at the very least attempt to give enough control to the player while also making enemies challenging, this is just "there is no strategy, die" but in the form of a single enemy gimmick. I believe this is mostly a fault of the 2D environment, it's something that i'm surprised doesn't seem to have been looked over as much as it should have. If you come from Risk of Rain 2 and are used to actually feeling like the game gives you a crumb of power while being fun, then you're probably gonna find that this game offers nothing in comparison. Almost no chests per stage, an alarmingly wide spread of items that offer minuscule impact to your gameplay, shrines having a consistent chance of giving you equipment repeatedly, and characters like artificer feeling very weak while others like enforcer, loader, and drifter being given insane gimmicks are just a handful of consistent problems that really take the fun out of the game.
Maybe I'll have a change of heart if they go over the weak characters and offer buffs, and when they add the mouse aiming, which is another big problem but I didn't mention it because other people have, plus the devs already adressed it.

While I still prefer Risk of Rain 2 overall this game is a good way to waste some time while getting folded in the process.

I was a big fan of the original Risk of Rain, but wasn't super into the second. It was pretty fun, but just didn't bring the same joy. This game however, this brings joy. Risk of Rain Returns is a glorious return to form, with beautifully redone visuals, new characters, items, enemies, and more. There's plenty of new features to justify the price tag, and lots of gameplay customization options.

The difficulty got me aggravated for a while, but it comes with the territory of roguelikes. With that being said, it feels good to learn the playstyles of each character and master your favorites. I didn't end up beating the game until putting over 50 hours into it, and there's still so much more to unlock. 
Also, Providence Trials are cancer. I don't know if I'll ever have the patience to get all the achievements, but I've currently have over 50% completed. I've been playing Risk of Rain for probably 6 years or more, and am happy to see the series expand and grow.

[h2]Pros[/h2]
+ Solid gameplay
+ The theme of RoR is as classy as ever.
+ Good class spread
+ Decent build variety across runs.

[h2]Cons[/h2]
- Running across maps with a lot of it being kind of empty is just really unrewarding.
- Platforming alternates between being simple and being too slippery depending on your speed.
- Control inputs feel clunky. From minor details like aim being where you face to not having much control over your momentum (in a platformer...) and the more jarring things like attacks needing to play out before a skill input can be received.

-----------

[h1]Summary[/h1]
It's a fun enough game and if I rated in a vacuum, I would actually recommend it.
RoR:Returns is nowhere as much of a lightning-in-a-bottle experience as RoR2.
Nor is it as good a platformer roguelite of any note, from Spelunky to Dead Cells.
As it is now, there's dozens of roguelite platformers I'd recommend over this if you want to see the true potential of this genre, which I'm sad to say, for my current 11 hours, RoR:R hasn't matched.

I don't have enough time on this game to give more feedback on the intricacies of the game, so this review may receive updates if I change my mind at some point. For context, I've not played the OG RoR.

Some characters have skills that didn't seem that helpful in single player game play for speed which is a large component of the game. However, with friends you can use any character as long as someone on the team has speed. Once you get the hang of the game I can see how almost any character would be possible for single player. Art is cool, concept is fun, getting loaded on items is satisfying, playing with friends can limit the number of items each of you get, short 15-30min games depending on your speed.

The updated art and animations do wonders for clarity in this game and there are a lot of little qol details all over the place. The game was about zooming out as far as you were comfortable with and dodging tons of various enemy attacks which really cannot be avoided by simple disengage/run away tactics. Now it's easier to see the enemies, what they're up to, etc.
QOL includes: Ability to leave a floor after beating the boss, rather than ALL enemies. Tighter controls and small movement changes, like skill buffering and the ability for certain characters to "strafe" to some degree, make the game way more comfortable. Accessibility options that let you drastically cut enemy damage output, great for if you want to explore stages.

There are options to change the rulesets to more similarly resemble the original RoR, so I can say that RoRR is the definitive version to own.

This was mostly to praise the improvements RoRR made on the classic formula, but here's the general rhythm this game follows.
Survivor crashes on a semi-randomized environment(stages are pre-built levels but there are several variants for each stage) and scrounges for items while searching for the teleporter. You want to balance item collection with speed of progress... because the game's difficulty is on a clock and everything gets a lot harder every 5 minutes.
After going through several stages there's a temple stage and you can choose to loop or to teleport back to the ship you abandoned in the intro, using the ship to ultimately escape the planet.
There are tons of fun characters and items, the way you need to fight enemies and avoid their attacks is the brutal star of the show. Early on you'll find enemies simple and inept but later there will be some devious attack patterns that require thoughtful movement to avoid, and then you're fighting dozens of enemies at a time. Frightful.
Tons of fun items, there seems to be this wonderfully inconsistent consistency to the game. Hard to explain, you can often rely on finding certain items you feel like you "need" until you get a run where you don't find those but you're still fine just thanks to totally different circumstances.

TL;DR - play as a few pixel tall character fighting tons of slightly more pixels tall enemies in this interesting take on the rogue like formula. Balance the constant race against the difficulty increasing clock with item collection, have fun with nasty attack patterns from hectic mobs of enemies. btw the final boss is so awesome, I hope you enjoy.

I recently had the pleasure of diving into the highly anticipated "Risk of Rain Returns," and let me tell you, it exceeded all my expectations and then some! This game is an absolute masterpiece that effortlessly combines the best elements of its predecessor with fresh, exciting features that make it a must-play for both fans of the series and newcomers alike.

The first thing that struck me was the stunning visual upgrade. The art style retains the charm of the original game but with a level of polish that's truly awe-inspiring. The attention to detail in the character designs, environments, and special effects is nothing short of breathtaking. The world of Risk of Rain has never looked this vibrant and alive, making each playthrough a visual treat.

But visuals alone don't make a great game, and "Risk of Rain Returns" knows that. The gameplay is where this title truly shines. The core mechanics that made the original a hit are still present and refined, providing a satisfying blend of challenge and reward. The addition of new characters, each with unique abilities and playstyles, adds an extra layer of strategy to the mix. It's a joy experimenting with different combinations to find the perfect synergy for your playstyle.

The level design is another standout feature. The procedurally generated worlds are more dynamic and diverse than ever, keeping the gameplay fresh and exciting with each run. The sense of exploration is heightened, as you never know what challenges or treasures await around the next corner. It's this unpredictability that keeps you coming back for one more run, and then another, and another.

The soundtrack deserves special mention, as it perfectly complements the game's intense and atmospheric moments. The music seamlessly transitions between calm exploration and heart-pounding battles, enhancing the overall immersive experience.

In conclusion,  is a triumph. It successfully builds upon the strengths of the original while introducing new elements that elevate the experience to new heights. Whether you're a long-time fan of the series or a newcomer looking for a captivating roguelike experience, this game is an absolute gem. Get ready to embark on an unforgettable journey filled with challenge, discovery, and a whole lot of fun!

Across all entertainment media, video games, films, novels, etc., it is usually rather difficult for remakes to live up to the glory of the original. At least, in my opinion. The only remakes I've ever played that actually surpassed the original were the remakes of the first two Metroid games, the remakes of the first two Pokemon games, and Risk of Rain Returns.

Not only does it respect the original and capture what made it fun and interesting, it adds new modern gameplay elements from Risk of Rain 2, and it doesn't even stop there. New, never seen before content, all over the place. It's almost like playing a whole new Risk of Rain game.

I recommend to anyone that likes action-platformers, and/or roguelikes, but if you haven't yet, go for Risk of Rain 2 first. You won't miss anything story-wise, and Risk of Rain 2 is a much more versatile game that is more open to beginners new to the series. Not that it's hard or anything, it's just not right for everyone.

Its a return to the classic Risk of Rain, (hence the name), including several new characters, items, and secrets to find, some of which originate from Risk of Rain 2. On top of that, the Providence Trials are an amazing way to just play the game, without having to start a full run. Some of the trials are fun enough to spend hours on just trying to beat your highscore, and I appreciate how many unlocks you can get are found there. If I'm honest, the game is extremely difficult right out of the box, and you really need to unlock a few items and characters before you can really enjoy the game, however, a lot of items are very easy to unlock, and once you get them, you're set.
All in all, good game, buy.

As is tradition, I must write a review for the Steam Awards Nomination Badge. This game deserves it though. Great remaster of the original and the added content makes it even more fun. It's a bit less forgiving than RoR2 but overcoming the learning curve is a good experience.

Risk of Rain Returns - A Nostalgic Yet Refreshing Roguelike Adventure
 
Risk of Rain Returns maintains the addictive core gameplay of the original while adding exciting new elements. Playing as one of 15 unique Survivors with fresh abilities keeps the experience dynamic. Personally, the Huntress's hit-and-run style was immensely satisfying.

The departure from automatic homing shots in the sequel adds a welcomed challenge, demanding precision. The introduction of a platforming element and potential fall damage adds strategic depth. The adjustment becomes second nature, enhancing the overall experience.

Enemy Dynamics create a dynamic environment, requiring adaptability. Some enemies can't navigate certain terrain, while others possess unique traversal abilities, keeping every encounter unique and challenging.

The game's Visuals and Atmosphere retain a distinct style, revitalizing Petrichor V. Hazardous lava and towering heights in certain biomes intensify the atmosphere, reinforcing the need for constant movement and strategic positioning.

Conclusion: Risk of Rain Returns is a nostalgic yet refreshing journey for fans of the roguelike genre. Whether you're familiar with the series or a newcomer, the game's thoughtful additions and commitment to the signature gameplay make it a must-play for any roguelike enthusiast.

Pretty good game. I played through the original ror a few times, wasn't really a fan, but i have spent 1k+ hours on ror2. Ror returns is fun and new, but i don't see myself playing it for more than 20 or so hours. and 10 hours, i was able to beat the game, unlock all but 2 survivors, get most of the items unlocked, did almost all the providence trials, and a few artifacts. Some providence trials seem a little too unbalanced and unfair, like the fireball artificer and the shotgun enforcer, where i spent 10+ tries and couldn't even get halfway, while most others i could do in 5 or less. Some trials are also just annoying like the pilot parachute one, took me forever because it's essentially just trial and error to figure out the best routes and items. No doubt there is a decent amount of content, but 2D games are not my style, so i'll probably just go back to ror2 when dlc2 comes out

Edit: At 69 hours (nice), i have beaten all the providence trials and beaten judgement on 6 survivors so far, as well as unlocked almost item, artifact, skin, and log book

A lot of subtle improvements over the original that make it feel significantly better to play. Most survivors can use their primary and move at a reduced speed instead of being stationary. Skills that require rapid button presses can be just held down now (with an accessibility feature). There's a lot of cooperative skills--and on many different survivors--that retain their effectiveness in single-player. When you die in multiplayer, you are given a second chance as a drone (for that stage) and your friends can give you items. It only has minor hiccups on the steam deck: inviting friends cannot be done without the touchscreen or simulating mouse control; and there is occasional performance issues. This was my most anticipated game this year, and I was not disappointed.

I messaged him to ask it how it was and he said it was fantastic and I should totally get it. Thing was on sale too, on day one.

Risk of Rain Returns keeps the original essence but spruces it up with enhancements for a better gaming adventure.

Pros:
[list]
    [*]Easy entry for newcomers with tons of replay value.
    [*]Maintains fidelity to RoR1 while introducing valuable additions like continuous shooting and stage teleportation without enemy clearance.
    [*]Strikes a balance between enemy health levels for a more engaging experience.
    [*]Customizable damage sliders apart from difficulty settings add flexibility.
    [*]Incredible soundtrack.
[/list]

Cons:
[list]
    [*]Small in-game and menu UIs even at the highest setting.
    [*]Lack of a save feature remains frustrating for shorter gaming sessions for gaming on desktop.
[/list]

Compared to the original Risk of Rain...

Most of the items are the same.
Most of the characters are the same.
Most of the monsters are the same.
All of the maps are the same.
The secret spots and artifact locations are the same.
The final boss fight is the same.
Even all the Steam achievements are the same.

The Providence Trials are new. Some are unique and I like them, while others can be very frustrating. I'm not sure I like how many things you can unlock from Providence Trials instead of a normal run. Most of the trails can be finished in a few minutes.

I'd tentatively recommend this game. I wouldn't recommend it to people like me who have hundreds of hours in the original game and got all the Steam achievements. There's no way I'm doing it all again. To everyone else, I'd recommend it over the first since they'll probably be updating this game a lot.

to all the risk of rain 1 fans, i can't recommend this game enough - it remixes and enhances many aspects of the original, and quirks of controls seem to be receiving a fix soon. tons of fun new ways to play, unique new abilities that play with the design space of the original game.
to everyone else: please, *please* don't expect this game to be risk of rain 2 - it's not, and it never will be; it can't be, that game was a third person shooter in 3d, this game is not that, notably, and will play very differently. survivors will play differently! and things will feel different! being in 2 dimensions creates an entirely different design space, and the mechanics play into that. there is no aiming, you aim by moving; there are only two directions, towards the enemies and away from them. the game has a lot to offer if you meet it where it's at, but don't go in expecting "2d risk of rain 2." that game doesn't and cannot exist.

The crowd this game is trying to appease is the veterans looking for a feeling of Nostaliga. If you're like me and didn't play this game back in the day but played RoR2 first then I would strongly advise against getting it. 

Pros: 
1. Some of the abilities feel cool I guess. 
2. A lot of characters to unlock right from the start. 
3. At least the game was cheap as dirt. 

Complaints: 
1. Maps are way too big for how absolutely empty they feel. Feels like you can't find loot and finding the teleporter is a massive pain.
2. Moving around is slow and clunky and both jumping + the "movement utilities" feel absolutely pathetic. 
3. Item text is too small and vanishes too quickly imo. Still don't know what half of things I picked up did.  
4. The maps are terrible and uninspired from an artistic point of view. None of them stand out to me. 
5. The power scaling feels like it's all over the place and extremely inconsistent. Sometimes I'd get lots of items and it felt like it didn't matter and other times I'd barely have any items and it'd go about the same as any other time. 

TLDR; It's boring and I'd much rather be on RoR 2 or bang my head against a game like Noita than continue to slog through another dull moment of whatever this is.

rorr really just improves on EVERYTHING from the original, easily replacing it

i LOVE the removal of having to clear out all enemies before teleporting, all the characters feel super unique and require different skill sets and skill levels to be effective with them, and DUDE the multiplayer is awesome (tho the "force item sharing" option is kind of useless with stages this big and no ping system. your friend is never going to find the item you leave on the floor for them)

dodging enemy fire by jumping often feels like a toss up, mainly because of how limited your movement is in 2D, but that's okay imo. it just kind of forces you to really outscale the enemies or else you DIE die.

on the subject of scaling though, the items feel way more impactful, and even with reduced proc chaining compared to ror2 they still feel like they redefine the way you do damage with every new one. really great game feel there

risk of rain returns is a faithful remaster of the original risk of rain game, and man, they did an amazing job at that. course, i suck at the game so i can't say too much, but it's really well done and i love it. my only few complaints would be that you can't really aim your abilities and attacks, and that remote play together could work a bit better, but aside from that the game is perfect. the animations, sound design, art, characters, new skills and new options, new enemies, and most importantly, the outstanding remastered soundtrack by Chris Christodoulou really make the game for me. 

as for price, games nowadays tend to just be getting more and more expensive as time goes on, which really sucks because most of us don't have a wallet that can keep up, but risk of rain returns has a more than fair price and is worth every cent.

Game is fine but there's tons of problems for a remastered : 

- The very poor mobility is horrible, but once few items you can go everywhere, I don't like that, it should be way more consistent and be less clunky in early
- Elites in general are busted dealing way to much dmg for how the RNG is on generating monsters (can combo on some nasty shit)
- Cremator is just uber broing and made you travel through the whole map.. There's 2, and both of their attacks are super strong, their projectiles travel through the whole map too.
- Bee monsters shooting 3 projectiles is completly dumb specially on Elite form, becoming a whole boss as its own, and most aerial monsters are a pain because of lack of mobility + lack of specific skills shooting diagonals (not all heroes have that or high cd)

the concept is great, the graphics are great, the music is great. the gameplay just doesn't feel rewarding enough for replayability. this is especially apparrent with the providence trials, where doing menial and difficult tasks with gimmick-y tools rewards you with nothing but a new character skin. that would be an awesome feature if the gameplay was rewarding for me. 

at the current moment it just isn't engaging enough to push me to discover all of its hard-to-navigate, frustrating, gimmicky features. not even achievements can get me to play more.

don't let my opinion speak for it -- try it out yourself. if you like roguelikes and hard games, pick it up.

It's a good expansion on the original game that makes it worth buying over the original. It borrows a lot of mechanics from ROR2 that makes the gameplay more streamlined and sensible for new players, or others coming from the second game. That's all it really does though: expands on the original. There are still glaring problems with the game as far as enemy and environment balancing, especially on monsoon difficulty. Certain new enemies such as swifts can spawn in massive amounts (and with many elites among them), which almost guarantees the end of your run. Certain bosses such as the toxic beast and cremator pose extreme threats, and for some characters are nearly impossible to kill without cheesing them. The extreme variability in chest spawns can also be run ending if you happen to suffer low numbers for multiple stages in a row. Some stages are also hard to navigate as the foreground and background are at times indistinguishable, which can lead to a frustrating death in some situations; the odd shape of the levels doesn't help either. Most of this I can dismiss as the brutal charm of the game, and these criticisms are easy for me to overlook; however, I know many won't feel the same way. I think the game is worth a try if you love a challenge or enjoyed the first game despite its shallow content. If you hated the 2013 version for any more than that: then I'm not confident that you would enjoy this one.

I barely played the original, but I've sunk countless days into RoR2 and after spending some time in this game, I plan to do so again. I love Roguelikes and this one takes the cake. It's so fun. I know dying and restarting is part of the experience with this genre, but RoR Returns makes is so much less annoying to start over from scratch, and as long as you still have things to unlock, every run feels important and every death a lesson. I have barely scratched the surface of content here and I'm already looking forward to future updates/expansions

This game is designed to be hard. Since it has just released, some elements (mainly a handful of the Providence Trials...) are still leaning into "Difficult and unfun", but for normal gameplay, the developers have made it way more flexible than they technically needed to.
In singleplayer, and multiplayer, there are options for intensity (and in the case of Multiplayer, the host can even let individual players tailor their intensity settings to their liking) in the form of buffing, or nerfing, both incoming and outgoing damage to/from the player.

Hopoo, as they always have, do NOT lock achievements or most unlocks behind not having artifacts or other "cheats" enabled. You could unlock everything with Sacrifice and Command (some of the most powerful artifacts available) while maxing out your outgoing damage and minimizing incoming damage, without that progress mysteriously not applying or vanishing.

Even if, like me, you have a tendency to get "skill issue'd", you'll still be able to pick this up and have fun, especially in Multiplayer.

Another thing to keep in mind is the game (as of writing) is still a pretty new release, so there's still a lot to iron out. Unlike other studios *cough* Bethesda *cough*, they aren't waiting for the community to fix the game and its bugs for them via mods.

The controls for this game are not good, but that was fine in RoR1 because the game wasn't finnicky. RoRR pretends it has good controls, and asks you to do speedrunner/ragegame nonsense with its awful pre-80s control scheme. Risk of Rain has always been a terrible platforming game, and all the new updates do is lean harder and harder on the weakest parts of the original, ultimately breaking them. I love it so far, my only critique(s) would be that It's absurdly hard even for rainstorm difficulty and the UI is a little bit small (in spite of the 2x zoom setting. Good game otherwise and definitely will play to completion.)

"Risk of Rain Returns" is a whole new game and a final farewell from Hopoo Games, the developers of the Risk of Rain series. It is not just a simple port or a graphical update, but a complete overhaul of the original game with new content, mechanics, and improvements. It is a tribute to the fans of the series and a celebration of the genre.

The first thing that stands out in Risk of Rain Returns is the beautiful graphics. The game has been remastered with high-resolution sprites, smooth animations, dynamic lighting, and stunning effects. The game looks gorgeous and runs smoothly on modern platforms. The art style is faithful to the original game, but with more details and polish. The game also features a new soundtrack by Chris Christodoulou, the composer of Risk of Rain 2, which adds to the atmosphere and mood of the game.

The gameplay of Risk of Rain Returns is similar to the original game, but with more depth and variety. The game still follows the same formula of landing on a mysterious planet, fighting through randomly generated levels, collecting items, and escaping. However, the game has added new features and elements that make each run more unique and challenging.

One of the new features is the introduction of two entirely new survivors: The Drifter and The Engineer. The Drifter is a resourceful brawler who can gather scrap from enemies and use it to spawn items that boost her and her teammates. She can also take the items for herself and unleash powerful attacks. The Engineer is a versatile survivor who can deploy turrets, mines, drones, and shields. He can also upgrade his equipment and switch between different modes. These two survivors join the 13 returning survivors from the original game, each with their own abilities and playstyles.

Another new feature is the addition of secrets and artifacts. Secrets are hidden areas and events that can be found by exploring the levels and interacting with the environment. They can reveal lore, items, challenges, or even new levels. Artifacts are gameplay modifiers that can be activated before or during a run. They can change the rules of the game, such as enabling friendly fire, randomizing item drops, or spawning more enemies. Artifacts can make the game easier or harder, depending on the playerâs preference.

The game also features an overhauled multiplayer mode, which supports up to four players online or locally. The multiplayer mode has been improved with new and better services, such as cross-play, matchmaking, leaderboards, and chat. The game also has a new mode called Prismatic Trials, which are seeded runs that change every 48 hours. In this mode, players can compete with each other on a global leaderboard, or cooperate to achieve the best time.

Risk of Rain Returns is a game that is faithful to its roots, but also expands and improves on them. It is a game that is fun, challenging, and replayable. It is a game that is full of surprises, secrets, and discoveries. It is a game that is a must-play for fans of the series and the genre. It is a game that is a masterpiece of roguelike design.
A worthy remake. The classic Risk of Rain experience, but with more stuff, and an updated artstyle that fits right in.

Risk of rain: double the pixels, double the chaos.

Positive:

Graphics 10/10: I want to highlight how amazing this game looks. For a pixel art game, it is incredibly vibrant and full of life and makes the 2013 risk of rain look like an NES game. The environments all look amazing and the character sprites are a lot more expressive now. I also really like the new logbook artwork and look forward to seeing each new drawing whenever I pick one up..

Gameplay 10/10: Although it's basically similar to the original risk of rain, there are some new tweaks in the gameplay that make it more enjoyable. The fact that you no longer have to eliminate every enemy on the map in order to move on to the next stage makes the game a lot less tedious.

Soundtrack 10/10: All of the amazing songs from the original ost have gotten some minor audio enhancements (I literally cannot tell the difference)  with the addition of 4 new ones. Coalescence Returns is especially my favorite and the vocals in it are amazing.

Accessability 10/10: I wouldn't normally rate a game based on this, but the amount of customization in the game's settings, both technical and gameplay-related, is very vast and I can tell they put a lot of effort into making this game enjoyable for everyone. They didn't have to add add in pre-made control mappings, but they did it anyways.

Negative:

There is only one very miniscule change from the original game to this version that I didn't like. In risk of rain (2013), you are able to assign multiple actions to one key.  This allowed me to make the "jump" and "climb rope" button both the same and made the games platforming less annoying. However, RORR does not let you do that. Again, this is very minor, but it kind of bothered me.

Other Notes:

The new providence trials range from stupidly easy to mindbogglingly difficult. I could never figure out how to beat the "scavenger hunt" one. 

I love finally being able to play this game's multiplayer without having to get a PHD in software engineering.

Enforcer and Mercenary canonically have beef. 

FINAL BOSS SPOILERS: [spoiler] I love the changes they made to the Providence fight. The surprise fourth phase genuinely caught me off guard the first time [/spoiler]

END CREDITS SPOILERS???: [spoiler] One thing the confused me is, during the end credits, there is a showcase of all the enemies that you encounter in the game with their sprite from Risk of rain (2013) next to their remastered sprite from this game. However, some of the new enemies that are exclusive to this game also have ror (2013) sprites. Did they just redraw them in the original game's artstyle for shits and giggles? Not sure why they did that, but cool.  [/spoiler]

FINAL SCORE: 10/10

That's about it. I enjoy Risk of Rain, always has been a frustrating experience full of joy and baddassery. But this game feels like something that would be an Easter Egg in another game not a standalone experience.

While I enjoyed the first Risk of Rain, a remake was not one that I was anticipating or even excited about. I had played so much Risk of Rain 2 and was content with it that a remake of the first game didn't really cross my mind. Once this released I bought it to give it a try and I am pleasantly surprised with all the quality of life changes. The biggest one being able to connect to friends on Steam to play. I haven't really messed with the providence trials too much but that also brings another mode and way to unlock alternative skills, something that wasn't present in the first game. 

 New survivors are great, I enjoy playing the entire cast, I like the challenge. Risk of Rain can be as difficult as you want it to be, or easier with the modifiers and artifacts, Personally I'm going to play this in my spare time with friends but I'll also go back to Risk of Rain 2 as well. If you enjoy the roguelike style, this is an entertaining 2D side-scrolling game that if you're coming from RoR2 can getting used to. If you enjoyed the original Risk of Rain, I implore you to take a chance on this remake. It can be fun with friends, but your mileage can vary based on your friend group based on the difficulty.

A great game and Im sure is an improvement to the original ROR1. My favourite is the animations and character models, they feel smooth but dont take away from the pixel like style of the original.

Music is straight up fire, and many stage themes are a straight improvement over the originals, such as surface tension returns, and the surprise Double F!$%ing Rainbow Returns. #ChrisDontMiss

However, it has many frustrating flaws that drag down the fun gameplay.

1) The inability to switch directions while firing or performing an action (This and the inability to move while shooting was originally also implemented in the original ROR1, however devs decided to forgo the inability to move while shooting in favour of a more flowy experience)

2) Parkour and gravity feeling extremely different to most platformers makes it a uniquely unsatisfying experience when performing tougher parkour challenges (such as the parkour towards the artifact of spite)

3) RNG on your runs dictating certain unlocks, such as miner's unlock and acrid's unlock only appearing on certain variations on certain maps, that might not even get chosen for your map pool because, rng? Its a mistake not to allow stages to change or be randomly picked while continuously looping (Just like how it was implemented in ROR2), having to LOOP AGAIN OR START ANOTHER NEW RUN because your wanted stage or variation did not get chosen for your stage pool.

4) Animation locking - Specifically the inability to cancel or use another input until your animation is finished, this is especially apparently for something like trying to climb ropes, only to realize you missed the jump because you were attacking during the attempt to climb the rope, which results in completely missing the rope.

5) MASSIVE STAGES - on stages 1 to 2, if you're not actively moving around trying to find the teleporter, it can take you upwards of 2 to 3 minutes to even find the teleporter in the first place. The scarcity of interactables exacerbates these issues to the point where you may die on stage 2 monsoon because you've been outscaled by the game, spending too long looking for the teleporter.

6) Providence trials - Easily the worst addition to the game. These are essentially level edited maps of the selection you encounter in game that are specifically tailored to the trial you complete, most of them are time trials, but some are survival trials, and some just feel like tutorials.

Some of these are enjoyable (mostly the mobility focused trials), such as commando's slide unlock, pilot's gliding trial, acrid's dissolving ambush and caustic sludge parkour trial or the final JUDGEMENT trial. But the majority are plain frustrating to go through, both because of the game's frustrating controls and jank preventing you completing the trial properly while being completely irrelevant to the main game (We all had fun during Hot-Rope Hop, right? RIGHT?!?!). 

Like huntress's alternate utility warp dart. In WHAT situation would that be more useful than an immediate blink with no room for error? Some abilities feel like they are just made for the trials, and that ends its usage which is completely idiotic in concept.
 
Some unlocks are also GATED BEHIND MULTIPLE PROVIDENCE TRIALS, such as kited blades locking out the Arcane Blades for players to pick up on their own runs. Because you DO NOT HAVE ACCESS TO ALL THE PROVIDENCE TRIALS AT ONCE, they must be completed in a certain sequence. So it is entirely possible for multiple unlocks to be gated behind EVEN MORE TRIALS.

Most of the trials here have nothing to do with the main game either. Players should not have to play ANY of these trials to unlock key items, and the items that ARE gated behind providence trial unlocks should have alternate ways to unlock them so players do not have to endure the frustration fest that is the trials. (Just like how the survivor skills have alternate unlocks, such as collecting 300 items, or getting to stage 25 etc.)

Having crowned around 90% of all the trials, I can confidently say it has been one of the most frustrating experiences that Ive ever experienced in an ROR game, and Ive fully 100% ROR2 with all the challenges which did not even come close to the amount of frustration Ive had with Provi trials.

[h1]One Of The Classic Roguelike Return In Its Former And New Glory.[/h1]

I have never played the original RoR before. I am not sure why but something about the game just never appeal to me. And now it returns, with both the original stuff and those from RoR2. Risk Of Rain Return's improved visual, and my love for the second game finally reel me in. I jump right into this reboot and fall in love with it immediately. Of course there are some stiff learning curves when it come to the transition from 3D to 2D run'n'gun, and the map knowledge as well. The experience stays the same. It is still the same running and gunning. It is still the same stacking items to make your stats absurdly high to the point of defying space-time continuum. It is still the same situation if you stop moving for 0.5 second a horde of elites will instantly vaporize you. In addition, RoRR also introduce a new way to unlock survivors' alternate abilities, which is something I cannot praise enough.

[h1]Things I Like About Risk Of Rain Return:[/h1]

[b]1. Gameplay[/b]
Coming from RoR2, the 2D platforming of RoRR gives me quite a pickle. You can go any direction in a 3D environment, but you can only go up-down-left-right in a 2D one. This, naturally, creates some frustration. However, as hours and hours dumped into the game, I grow to love this game, in a quite different way comparing to RoR2. Learning which enemy can climb ledges is important. You need to bait away the enemies with high mobility while gunning down others from the high ground. I would even say that RoRR focuses more on map knowledge than the second one. Because enemies also suffer from fall damage, baiting them into geysor with you is a great way to create breathing room and deal some decent damage. Another thing worth mentioning is that since you and your enemies are fighting on the same platform(except those accursed jellyfishes), abilities with homing trait or penetration are highly preferred. Again, because of 2D environment and Rain of Rain, later stages can become really chaotic with tons of enemies and visuals clogging your screen. It is just as terrifying as RoR2, and I love every second.

[b]2. Providence's Trials[/b]
This is the wonderful feature I love. One of the prominent characteristic of the RoR franchise is the challenge to unlock new survivors and their alternate abilities. Some may be easy like collect a certain amount of drone, but some can be really hard to pull off. I still vividly remember how many times I've attempted to unlock Bandit's alternate secondary. Now with Risk Of Rain Return, the hard challenges are still there, but there are alternative way to unlock the alternate abilities. Providence's Trials offer customized challenges that are designed around the unlockable abilities or mini games. For example, Huntress' "Where You Want To Be" trial allows players to practice using Warp Dart to teleport to various high platforms, while Bandit's "Retrograde" trial give players the taste "what if Castlevania but made with Risk Of Rain". Of course players are unnecessary to do those trials to get the abilities. The OG way still stands.

[b]3. Other Compliments[/b]
âThe music still slaps.
âCrazy item stacks to get god-like power.
âI love every survivor's ready-up animation.
âEach level hides lots of secret passages for unlockables and lore text logs.
âMany survivors, abilities, and skins to unlock.
âFunny that my favorite survivors in RoR2 become my least in RoRR.

[h1]Things I Dislike About Risk Of Rain Return:[/h1]

[b]1. Maps May Be Too Long, Or Empty?[/b]
This is the only major problem I have towards the game. I am not sure this is due to level generation or because of specific maps, but in many runs I often go through a lot of platforms and corners to find nothing at the end. It is frustrating to run around the whole map and has no way to spend the coins. In Risk Of Rain, finding items fast is just as important as your maneuver, and this situation not only wastes time but also might ruin the run because of the speeding up difficulty. Maybe it is done to hide secret passages, or maybe it is trying to connect different terrains together. No matter what, the frustration is there and I cannot deny it.

[b]2. Other Complaints[/b]
âFlying enemies can be massive pain in the butt for specific survivors.
âSome challenges in the main game are absurdly hard and RNG-reliant.

Would I recommend this game? Sure, it's a decent enough rougelike and the price point is pretty good. On these metrics this is a good game. However, as the product that comes after Risk of Rain 2? This is quite sad and a departure of quality.

It is important to preface that I think Risk of Rain 2 is one of the best rougelikes out there. The items are fun, the gameplay is compelling and immensely replayable, and though rng based in terms of items, with enough skill you can overcome most challenges. In this regard, it is a bit unfair to compare this game to that as it was almost certain the product wouldn't've measured up however that is the most apt comparison.

This game being a 2d side-scroller which is very different from RoR2 being 3d and leads to a bunch of downgrades from RoR2. First, it is significantly harder to dodge attacks. You WILL take damage which is pretty bad because that means you are much more reliant on items to protect or heal you. Unlike in RoR2 where skill can supplement, getting bad items means you might as well quit your run cause you're going to get killed eventually unless you are one of the 2 or 3 characters that can manage without.

Second, items are just way weaker here than in RoR2. I don't know what Hopoo has against fun, what with all the stupid, misguided decisions they made with nerfing items or mercenary in RoR2 but its in full force here. This again means you're much more reliant on items of the right types and quantities to get a decent run off the ground. 

Third, though fixed with enough time and getting used to things, the game gives you what I would consider to be the worst characters in the game to start with. For the aforementioned reasons, it's pretty rough. 

Fourth, the lack of inclusions of features from RoR2, like scrappers and 3d printers is disappointing to see. 
There are other nitpicks to the game but I will leave it as is.

Fifth, Providence Trials are neat. It is more content so regardless of the quality, that is always a plus. While some are fun, others lean more towards irritating, with a few (especially when trying to get gold ranks) being purely frustrating. The last providence trials not allowing you to select alternate abilities is very disappointing and lame as well.

Sixth, until I see more to prove me wrong online, there is a disappointing lack of secrets (unless you count unlocking items or artifacts which I do not). This was true of 2 as well so its sad to see that this has not changed.

TL;DR: This game is quite the step back from the fun and quality of RoR2 with the game being significantly more item and thus RNG reliant to get a good run going. Skill can still allow people to succeed in bad runs but the limiting 2d aspect of this game makes that be more of a matter of running away for awhile than proper kiting leading to boring gameplay. Do not let these criticisms fool you, this is a good game by regular metrics. However it is disappointing to see this be the follow-up from Hopoo, especially considering that this is what they decided to focus on after dropping support for RoR2 as fast as possible.

Here's a few random questions, trying to answer the question "Should you buy this?" 

[b]Do you hate roguelites as a genre, or do you hate 2d sidescrollers?[/b]
[list]
[*]If yes to either of those, you can probably skip this. Or just try it out, just in case your expectations are wrong.
[*]Otherwise, go on to the other questions:
[/list]

[b]If you never played RoR 1/2:[/b]
[list]
[*]Choose if you enjoy 3rd person shooters or 2d sidescrollers more, and buy the one you prefer. They're both excellent games, with similar content.
[/list]

[b]If you played RoR1 a decade ago:[/b]
[list]
[*]This can be a good excuse to replay the game, with some added content. Realistically a modded original RoR can give "better" results for now, but if you can't bother with modding, this is just objectively a better version of the game.
[*]If you did [b]not[/b] enjoy original RoR1, this remake probably won't change that. There's just more content and a few small(ish) tweaks.
[/list]

[b]If you played RoR2 and enjoyed it, but never played RoR1:[/b]
[list]
[*]Considering the content structure is somewhat similar, the main difference is just 3rd person shooter vs. 2d sidescroller. If playing a game with similar content but completely different gameplay sounds like a fun concept, go for it.
[/list]

As someone who never played the original, only Risk of Rain 2, this is a fun, but not perfect game.

Positives:
Great music
Great gameplay loop of Risk of Rain
Great artistic style
Many distinct characters
Actual procedurally generated stages


Negatives:
1. Base movement is a lot more restrictive than in RoR2. This means any mistake in platforming (which generally isn't too difficult, at least) can be extremely punishing. Comparing the game to RoR2 or Dead Cells (Another platforming roguelike), it feels like you have less options to outplay enemies with movement.
2. To not get lost on the procedurally generated stages or mess up your pathing, I felt obligated to zoom out the screen in options. While helpful, it also makes everything tiny and hard to look at on a laptop.
3. Items seem less impactful than in Risk of Rain 2. It might be just because I don't know what many of them do yet, but I haven't had the feeling of a run being "saved" by a godly item like in RoR2 or other roguelikes. I do understand that many of the same item concepts have vastly different implications in a 2D vs 3D game.
4. Combining all of these (slower movement, zoomed out screen, less impressive items), the game as a whole feels pretty slow paced. Not necessarily a bad thing, but personally I like my action roguelikes fast-paced.

Lot more listed in negatives simply because that's how the human mind works, but I still think the game is fun. I've already rage alt+f4'd a couple times, but I've always ended up loading it up again later.

A nice overhaul of the original Risk of Rain, though lacking in more modern quality of life changes (aiming, ability to save and quit during runs, being able to turn and attack, having to mash for combo characters, etc.). Fans of Risk of Rain 1 will get to enjoy the soundtrack again and experience what the newer items from Risk of Rain 2 feel like in a 2D environment, along with a couple of new characters. Not all of these characters and/or their abilities transitioned well between 3D and 2D though and it's VERY apparent. The difficulty for unlocking things, between Trials and Achievements, varies wildly, to the point where I've seen many people express frustration at attempting to achieve gold on the Trials. I think they're a great way to become acclimated to abilities or give the player fun ways to unlock new abilities/items, but gold metals in these give too little reward for the amount of effort most players will be willing to put towards achieving them. While this remake/re-release is nice for people like me who enjoyed the original and like to see the animation updates and have additional lore and nice pixel art to appreciate, the lack of quality of life updates suggests this is not a priority for Gearbox/Hoppo. Faithful remakes are nice and all, but you can take out the things that were bad and replace them. Their time has come and gone and not including these quality of life improvements feels lazy, or disingenuous to the players.

**I have played this game with roughly a dozen people, all with completely unique takes on the game. Read this review if you want to know if it is right for you.**

Risk of Rain Returns is a roguelite platformer open-world bullet hell. If this sounds appealing to you, go ahead and get the game. You will not be disappointed. If you are unsure of what that means or if is the right fit for you, continue reading.
   This game has an immensely high skill ceiling. Every time you die, and you will die, you will find yourself at fault for your death. Whether it be poor time management, bad dodging, or incorrect item choice, whatever happens to you is your fault. Whilst there is an immense amount of luck involved in this game, you can always win no matter what RNG says. The best way to describe it is in terms of poker: The game will always deal you a run or a flush, and it is up to you to bluff or bet your way to victory.

**People who will want this game**
   
+ If you love platformers, this is a game for you.
+ If you don't mind platformers but you just really want to find another Dead Cells, this game is certainly for you.
+ If you want more of that iconic action-packed strategy of the first two Risk of Rain games, this is for you.
+ If you love the tactics and strategy of RTS games but want something a bit more personal, get this game.
+If you love uncovering mysteries and hidden narrative 

**People who will not be satisfied with this game**
- If you do not like hardcore games
- If platformers are something you avoid
- If bullet hells like Just Shapes and Beats are too chaotic for you
- if being overwhelmed is not something you enjoy

Plenty of others will tell you how the game is played. Rather than summarize old information, I'll quickly hit the highs and lows of the product: 

+The art style is stunningly well-made.
+ The story underneath the surface of the roguelite is touching and intense.
+ Each Survivor feels like a completely new game.
+ Easily replayable into the hundreds or thousands of hours. Worth your money.
+ Excellent balance and unparalleled passion for a fair experience.
+ One of the best couch co-op games out there.
+Secrets galore!

- As of now, you have to zoom out to the max if you want to find items easily. This hampers the personality of the survivors and detaches you from your character. **Hoppoo is currently working on fixing this.**
- Two characters are slightly more powerful than the rest due to their speed (Huntress and Pilot).
- Can get very boring if you don't actively attempt to get better at the game.
-Parkour requires dexterity and could be unfavorable to people who dislike platformers.

I hope this educates your purchasing decision. Thank you for reading!

I grew up on the original game. We used to host LAN parties on the unsecured ports of the school's network and play together in class. It was not the most polished, and had some balancing issues, but it was fun for the time and one of the few games we could get to work on our laptops.

This remaster beautifully revitalizes that original game, fixing a lot of the balancing issues without removing any of the content, and instead adding plenty to it. 
It was always a harder game than RoR2, but now it feels fair with its difficulty, and I'm having tons of fun revisiting this remaster with the friends I made in RoR2, sharing my game knowledge with them as I re-explore the familiar terrain.

Also worth it for just the Providence Trials alone. Fun little time-killer minigames that will keep you hooked trying to get the gold scores.

This is it. They've done it again. If you are like me, and enjoy Risk of Rain 1 more than 2, or enjoy 2-D roguelites more than 3-D roguelite/roguelikes, you will be absolutely amazed at the quality Risk of Rain Returns has to offer. The highly improved pixel art, with much more fluid animations than the first, brings about a feeling of nostalgia while still feeling like a new game. Its familiar, yet it looks so dusted off and cleaned up that it feels good to play it. This is coming from a decade-old fan of the series.

The 2-D platforming is very similar to that of the original in terms of movement and physics. The environments and characters have been revamped to look more interesting while you are running about, killing the monsters on the different planets. Its the little things that count in a game like this, and especially in a remaster. For example, when Commando shoots, his hands alternate every second of firing to switch out which gun he is firing with. It is accompanied by muzzle flashes on his body and in front of the gun. The bullets don't go in a perfectly straight line when you use your suppressive fire, and every now and then one goes astray (and actually misses the target, too!). The details are immaculate, and the game looks beautiful in every aspect. 

The one downside to Risk of Rain Returns, in my opinion, is that we don't get a new soundtrack. I think most fans can agree, one of the best parts of the series is the incredible music by Christ Christodoulou. We get a few remixes at the end of the album, but just remasters throughout the stages while playing. It a minor complaintâbut if I am going to be honest, a new soundtrack was something I was looking forward to the most out of this game. 

To my knowledge, there are new items and/or items from Risk of Rain 2 that were put into the game, so I am highly looking forward to a new experience in this 2-D universe I am already accustomed to. I am excited to continue playing this game, and hopefully I can eventually get 100% of the achievements on it like I did the original. I love Risk of Rain, and I think I'm going to love Risk of Rain Returns, too.

It's how I *remember* RoR1 playing, including the absolutely insane difficulty compared to 2, with an art update and new characters that honestly revitalise how to approach it. The new graphics can be a bit weird if you're used to the old set, such as some platforms looking like they should end a lot earlier than they do, but they have also fixed how awkward it was setting up multiplayer games, which is a hell of a plus.

It really is just how you remember RoR1, for all that encompasses to mean, but with new content - like how Age of Empires 2 keeps getting new DLC. If they do keep adding to this and RoR2, I think there's a duo of incredibly solid games that you can keep going back to, here.
Risk of Rain 2 but 2d

Everything that made Risk of Rain 1 so awesome but fleshed out and given a fresh coat of paint. Returns preserves most of the original gameplay experience of RoR1 while making it feel less clunky and unfair which is very appreciated. 
In particular, it feels like they made the platforming slightly more forgiving; in the first game I would often waste a lot of time repeatedly failing basic jumps because they were unreasonably precise. You can also now (slowly) move while attacking which makes the game feel so much more dynamic and fair. 
The updated art style is simply phenomenal. It's beautiful and detailed pixel art that completely preserves the feel of the original designs while adding to them.
This is more than just a remake though. Returns ads a lot of awesome content like new survivors, items, alternative loadouts (like in RoR2), mechanics and more!
Overall I think Risk of Rain Returns is an excellent remake. I used to really like RoR1 but I stopped playing because of how difficult and clunky it was and never revisited it for those reasons. It was super awesome but some aspects of the gameplay just didn't feel good. I'm so glad there is now a version that addresses all these issues I had and improves the game as a whole. I can finally re-experience this fantastic piece of art.
Highly recommended both to those who used to play RoR1 back in the day and those wanting to experience it for the first time.

Amazing, classic rouge-like. If you're in love with the genre you don't need to wait for me to tell you it's any good. 

Otherwise, if you're completely new, it's essentially an arcade style game where you jump and shoot your way through a level, pick up items to power up, find the exit, fight a boss, and repeat 5 times until you beat the final boss. Except the twist is, it gets more difficult as time passes. And it's a VERY challenging game--the highest difficulty is no joke. There's loads of secrets and things to unlock for your next play through so you're not just stuck with the same thing ad nausea. 

As someone who sunk countless hours into the original and it's sequel, this was a highly anticipated game and boy it delivered. And it's only going to get better with mods. It's one last hurrah from the original devs before the bigger publisher took over, and hopefully, the franchise will get even better with time. For now though, what we have is already a masterpiece.

[h1]An excellently polished and very faithful remake[/h1]

[b][u]Pros:[/u][/b]
[list]
[*]The tight, core 2D gameplay of RoR1 is back and better than ever.
[*]Beautiful spritework, both for old and new content. It all captures what the original game was going for and looks nice while doing it.
[*]Legendary soundtrack. Chris Christodoulou's work is unparalleled. 
[*]The Providence Trials are a wonderful addition.
[*]New content added to regular runs to keep the game fresh, such as new items, stages, enemies, alternate skills, and [spoiler]four[/spoiler] new playable survivors.
[*]Actual online multiplayer this time, and it seems to work seamlessly.
[*]Plenty of quality of life adjustments to the returning survivors, such as Engineer's turrets retaining his items like in RoR2.
[*]You get a LOT of content out of this for $15.
[/list]

[b][u]Cons:[/u][/b]
[list]
[*]Abrupt difficulty spikes are present in some of the Providence Trials (which they seem to be taking feedback on)
[*]The game performance dips tremendously with certain artifact combinations/when too many enemies are present. (Though this is only in very extreme cases.)
[/list]

[b][u]Conclusion:[/u][/b]
If this is Hopoo's love letter to fans before moving onto other things, I honestly couldn't have asked for anything better. Risk of Rain 1 was already a notably solid and fun game, but this remake manages to push it even further. So much thought and care was put into every little detail that this was probably what the devs had originally envisioned for this game back when it was just a college project, but they just didn't have the resources to do it at the time. But now we all get to witness their vision in its beautiful glory. The amount of effort put into making sure this game feels like the original both aesthetically and mechanically, but still making it feel "fresh" is something to behold. If you're a fan of the roguelite genre you can't go wrong with this game, especially at just $15.
