As someone who never played the original game, getting the chance to see what RoR1 was all about is really cool. Giving the RoR2 audience a chance to experience RoR1 with a BUNCH of extra content on top, PLUS a visual overhaul and music remaster is fucking sweet. Even better, the people who enjoyed Risk of Rain 1 get to see their game get HUGE upgrades in all the right places. Another point to add is that as someone who likes reading all of the logbooks, getting to own both games and read logs from each one and connect events and references together is really fun. Game can be hard as a bitch on Monsoon though. The stages are quite big which I think is cool, but it can definitely be a pain in the ass sometimes. The transition from big open 3D environments to a 2D platformer can be a turn off for some, but I've found myself adjusting fine.

All in all, awesome fucking game, worth the money 10/10 would die on monsoon again.

For those unfamiliar with the title, this is a wonderful roguelike.  You play a survivor of a crashed cargo ship (one of several to choose from) who must survive on a hostile world.  Good thing all those cargo crates that fell out of the ship are full of useful items...
The art has been updated in a way that is really lovely.  Not just that, but the visual style is more clear.  Any glance at the promo material will show you the pixel style of the game.
The gameplay is fun, but is best with friends to co-op.  Not that the single player is bad, but it's comparing a home run to a grand slam.  A play session takes between 20 and 45 minutes, typically.  Well, unless you beef it on stage one, but that *never* happens...
And finally, the music is so, so good.  You could just put it on even when you're not playing and it will make your daily life feel a lot more epic.  I cannot praise the music enough.
Simply an outstanding masterpiece of art, music and gameplay.

I find satisfaction in both the game-play and soundtrack, executed well in this remastered edition. However, what I noticed the most was how near-perfectly the art style was remastered. As someone well-versed in games featuring pixel art graphics, I can attest that the artists have excelled in revitalizing both the art and game-play.

The inclusion of creature lore in the monster log adds a fair bit of depth, and the finely composed and mixed soundtrack enhances the overall aesthetic experience. Do keep in mind that this game is currently in its alpha stages, and displays a noticeable presence of bugs. Nevertheless, it's noteworthy that updates are actively improving the overall experience.
A great addition to the Risk of Rain franchise.

One of my favorite remakes of all time.

Basically, it includes every gameplay content from the game it's based of while reworking some aspects to better fit today's standards. It also adds new stuff including survivors, items, and artifacts. There's also quality of life addition such as being able to walk slowly while shooting which you'll see a lot, it is however a bit janky at times.
The soundtrack you know and love also returns, with a few new tracks which sounds amazing where they are played.

The only change that'll take me some time getting used to is the difficulty ramping up slightly quicker than in Risk of Rain 1, runs are naturally slightly more random due to having more items in the roster should you pick default game rules and play without Artifact of Command.
Some of the things I don't like about this game as of so far are the fact that you face numerous of airborne enemies during runs, which can be bothersome given how often they spawn and how some classes can struggle on dealing with them. There are Providence Trials which I enjoy for the most part! However, some are really unfair to get a gold crown score on and takes numerous of tries due to luck being involved.

For a remake of a game that I really enjoyed playing 10 years ago, having this remake is one of the best things that I could have. It may be slightly more difficult than what I remember, but I'm having as much fun with it as I did back then. Almost all of the past experience from the original game will transfer well to Returns.

If you enjoyed Risk of Rain 1 by any chance or is interested in finding out what a 2D Rougelike would be like, I'd recommend that you buy this game. You'll really enjoy it.

Not the same kind of game as Risk of Rain 2. The looting cycle is the same, technically, but the way you have to strategize and deal with combat is very different. You're a lot weaker in a lot of ways than you are in RoR2; dodging's a lot harder, mobility abilities are worst, shooting slows you to a crawl, and you need to fiddle with positioning to shoot flying enemies because most characters only have attacks that shoot in a straight line horizontally. Fits with the theme of this game, which is being a desperate survivor having crash-landed, as opposed to RoR2 where the characters are part of a professional rescue team.
Also, for speedrunners (or just people who get bored of doing the same runs over and over): the Trials gamemode adds a lot of options for time attack or for trying to get insanely high scores, with a lot less RNG than the main game. The final trial especially.
The game's lacking some peripheral features right now; modding support doesn't really exist so a lot of those very helpful UI mods that 2 had aren't available yet or are very annoying to install. And as for new gameplay content, good luck.
If you've never played 2, I'd probably get that instead, but if you have and you want a totally new way to play Risk of Rain, Returns has that.

i originally found out about the risk of rain franchise through risk of rain 2 and i 100%'d it after 300 something hours and i LOVED that game. though i never bothered with the original. but i got excited when this got announced. so far i've put 56 hours, 127 runs, and 44 providence trials into the game. i've been having so much fun with it and i do plan on 100%'ing it and i can tell ill put as many hours into it as i did with ror2.

the pixel art and animations are absolutely stellar and i can tell each sprite has a lot of time and care put into them. definitely took a LONG time to make all of them. the artwork in the logbook is amazing and the stages look very nice as well.

i do have to admit i do NOT like 2D platformers (terraria is fine tho) but after i got used to it, it felt natural. though i am very excited for mouse aiming when that comes out in a later patch. gameplay can be kinda spammy at times, especially in the end game, depending on which character you play though.

so i am very excited to keep playing and you NEED to buy this for its price cause it will give you a great time. im a huge fan of the risk of rain franchise so ye
(multiplayer is awesome too)

Such an amazingly developed love-letter to the original. Hats off to Hopoo Games for another great entry into the Risk Of Rain series.

Positives:
- Amazingly done sprite-work
- The scaling feels slower than ROR1, but faster than ROR2, leading to a fair but tough time crunch
- The providence trials are overall nice and provide a good challenge in trying to get a gold rank.
- The characters feel fluid to play
- Better Providence fight
- More items & artifacts :D
- Mountain shrines are rewarding while challenging
- Wayyyyyy more stage varieties (6 each)

There are a few things though,
- The levels are massive, and sometimes it feels like there isn't enough loot for the stage size.
- Flying enemies are pretty annoying, and can be especially frustrating to fight on specific survivors.
- The providence trials, while most are fun, some are tedious and frustrating to do. There is no way to get around doing these, as some items are locked behind frustrating trials.
- Commando is still dogsh*t and under-powered when compared to the other survivors.
- Mouse aiming isn't a thing yet, but will be implemented later
- Because of the level varieties, grinding for some specific achievements can be annoying, given that you can only get them on one specific variant of a stage
- Third game in the series, STILL NO SAVE FUNCTION!!!

These are just some nitpicks, but if you can see past them you discover an amazing game that has plenty of hours to dump into, a must play for anyone who enjoyed ROR1, and a new adventure to those introduced through ROR2.

This game is amazing, takes the time out of my day.

Loved Risk of Rain 1, so it's a pleasure to return to it.

The new coat of paint is very nice, pixel art's quite crisp and neat looking without being too far away from its origins.
The new survivors are extremely fun, except one. (Even after some fixes, I still think a certain returning survivor from Risk of Rain 2 just feels bad to play as.)
Providence Trials were quite interesting, it's very cool to see the fun ideas and twists the team came up with within Risk of Rain. Some of them would require slight tweaking though. Difficulty was all over the place.

Multiplayer is not that great of you come from RoR2 though. Items are scarce, and except a text chat, there's no method of ingame communication that eases it a little bit. No pings or such.

Another small complaint I have would be that levels are huge and annoying to navigate at times, which makes finding the teleporter quite the chore. A bigger radius on particles would help. (Especially for people playing at higher scaling.)

Overall had a great time with the game and I wholeheartedly recommend it. Enjoyed it and will continue to enjoy it.

If you enjoyed Risk of Rain, I guarantee you'll love Risk of Rain Returns. If you think "well, I already have the first one, I don't need the HD remake" - think again.
While we revisit a lot of characters, items and stages, Risk of Rain Returns is still a fresh and unique experience, with a ton of new and improved features and additions. Where Risk of Rain is like a memory of a place, one where details have begun to fade and we lose track of what it actually looked like, Risk of Rain Returns is a return to that place, with fresh eyes, where we can see that while we're back where we started, there were so many things we forgot along the way.
A massive improvement, in both graphics and gameplay, but with so many new features, characters, items, stages, enemies, that simply calling it "a remake of Risk of Rain" feels reductive. It's a new, fresh game that also encompasses the original Risk of Rain.

Improves on the original in every single way with beautiful new pixel art and remastered/recomposed songs from Chris Christodoulou that blew me away (especially Surface Tension Returns and Double Fucking Rainbow Returns). Even though I haven't finished the game on my own yet (it is [i]very[/i] challenging), it has proved itself to be one of my standout games of the year.

There are some issues that plenty of people have pointed out in their reviews but most will soon be patched. The remaining complaints are just... baffling to me. It feels as if people have come in with expectations that the game would be like Risk of Rain 2 which is clearly not what the developers were setting out to do with this project. I'm disappointed to see the game drop a percentage point in its approval rating every time I look at the steam page. Please understand that this game is [i]not[/i] for everyone and it is certainly not RoR2 -- it should not be held to the same standards.

For $15, it is a spectacular bargain deal. If you are a fan of challenging roguelikes, do yourself a favor and buy this game.

And to the people who say this should have been a free update to Risk of Rain 1: fuck you. You fail to understand how much tireless effort must go into a quality remaster like this. I am appalled by some of the privilege and entitlement some people have in this community.

EDIT: I finally beat the game in singleplayer! Finally...

I hate this game.  Around every new corner is something frustrating awaiting the player.

The first thing players will notice is that they can't shoot backwards easily: the player has to do an annoying backwards step, then click while they're still moving backward, and then they can walk forward again, but only moving at half speed.  The second thing players will notice after a couple levels is that they can't hit flying targets! Players have to wait until enemies happen to swoop down low enough to equal height, or try to jump-hit them, which they can't do, because of the third problem.  The jump height is microscopic.  Frequently there are staircase jumps where the player has to jump, collide halfway up the next step, wait for character to fall, and then jump again; all the while hardly moving horizontally. Controlling the character feels awful.

The move speed is so slow and the maps are gigantic.  Compared to monsters, movement feels fine and balanced because of the mobility ability. But after clearing a bunch of enemies, there's empty space to traverse--the maps are huge and procedurally generated--and the player has to waste their time walking around in search of the exit portal.  Meanwhile, the difficulty ticks up every second, and the player isn't getting any items to scale comparably.  The portal could be in any corner of the HUGE maps.  How do you have a good run on Hard difficulty? Get lucky finding the portals quickly.  Now THAT feels bad.  Risk of Rain 2 didn't have this problem because the 3D camera lets players see so much further.

Once arriving at the portal, it summons a boss and player has to "survive" enough time before they can escape.  Let me stress this: the portal text says "STAY ALIVE..!" with a timer ticking above the player's head (x/90 seconds) and an objective at the bottom of the screen reading "Stay alive!"  Nothing about that experience informs the player that they are REQUIRED to kill the boss to advance.  In any game I would usually do this anyway, because it means more loot/scaling, but a few times it was inconvenient so I tried to...literally just survive!  Only to find out that I must hunt down the boss.  Okay, one time learning mistake, but it's not always an easy task (new player experience matters!).  Sometimes, the boss is actually across the map!  The player must follow a red arrow guiding them to the boss, forcing them to backtrack large distances.  By the way, time's ticking and difficulty increasing.  The developers seemed to intentionally design a map [lava map] to work this way.  On another map, the boss de-agro'd and walked away. Of all bosses, this was the Imp Overlord, which should be teleporting to the player to hit them.  Simply infuriating.

Crucial to a platformer is the affordance given to said platforms.  The game fails again.  Constantly I would run straight across a large level platform and was surprised to find I was falling (yes, there's fall damage).  The art is not clear to the player what is and is not a platform.  Platforms briefly blend into slightly greyer drawings of themselves (of distance two player widths), then reconnect with other large platforms of the same art style.  I know this sounds ridiculous (this guy MUST be a bad player luhmouw), however the game tries very hard to make the levels look good (they do, with very diverse maps), and it interferes with my gameplay.  I tried to recalibrate myself to the game, but then I swung too much in the other direction--I didn't think valid locations were reachable!  Adding to the problem, there are some secret locations where the player can pass through normal walls and reach what looks like an isolated pickup inside a mountain.  Even more, there seem to be some locations that can't actually be reached without 2 (or 3?) jumps.  Nothing is as it seems.

My final major complaint is the lack of content.  Literally all concepts of characters, items, and enemies are re-used from Risk of Rain 2, the only difference being the 2D platformer format, so the game already feels stale.  I played RoR2 to completion and it's just grind to unlock everything I already know about.

More minor bad things:
[list]
[*] All abilities have small delays so it's next to impossible to jump hit enemies.
[*] The huntress doesn't have any way to stop fall damage in her kit, and the game has a ton of high ledges where players can accidentally fall.
[*] Climb speed also feels slow, so it really sucks trying to get back up after falling.
[*] No movement ability increases vertical height.
[*] Some ladders were hard to discern.
[*] I was forced to fight a bunch of mobs at the exit portal in a small passageway, and some background pillar was a random ladder for no reason and I would grab it occasionally, slowing me down.  The ladder was about 3 character lengths tall and just hit a [real] ceiling.
[*] Character model is hard to discern from all the on-screen noise.
[*] I also can't tell if my partner is on top of me inside all the enemies.
[*] I wish my health bar also appeared next to my party-mate's at the top left so I only have to check one place.
[*] The player can use the mouse if it feels better for them (as it does for me), but Dear God please just let me aim with the mouse, it feels so bad.
[*] The good parts of the game aren't enough to justify the pain of big maps and slow player speed.  Yet Another Game That Is Balanced Around Wasting My Time. YAGTIBAWMY
[/list]

Oh boy, a Risk of Rain remake with better graphics and actually usable multiplayer? Don't mind if I do...

Pros:
-Very nice pixel art that, in most cases, feels like a direct upgrade to the original's.
-New survivors, items and a handful of new gimmicks like temporary items (plus updates to old survivors' kits)
-Several general gameplay refinements, like not needing to hunt down every enemy in the level to move on to the next
-Several different ways to adjust difficulty to your liking, from being able to set modifiers to the amount of damage taken/received, how quickly the in-game timer fills via the three difficulty settings, and being able to change between several of the remake's reworked gameplay mechanics and the original's. This is also on top of the unlockable artifacts that have all sorts of bizarre or interesting effects on the gameplay. At its baseline, this game is very challenging.
-Just feel like playing the original but with working multiplayer and a new coat of paint? There's a setting for that too.
-How quickly the game physically runs isn't tied to framerate anymore so it doesn't feel like time is moving slower the more enemies are on the screen, among other performance improvements! Hurray!

Cons:
-While in most areas the game is a visual upgrade to the original, sometimes the maps feel too busy and not very clear about what is and isn't an obstacle/ladder/able to be walked on.
-This seems... Harder than I remember. Like much harder. People coming from Risk of Rain 2 will probably feel like this game's Drizzle difficulty without any difficulty adjustments is on par with RoR2's Monsoon difficulty. The new Providence Trials are neat in concept, but wow, are they all very difficult- and not able to have their difficulty tuned like the main game...
-You have offered to the shrine and gained nothing. You have offered to the shrine and gained nothing. You have offered to the shrine and gained nothing. You have offered to the shrine...

Worth it for functional multiplayer and some new characters, abilities, unlocks, and artifacts.

To start off: I very much enjoy this game. However, once you begin playing co-op and/or unlocking and playing more characters, the cracks begin to show. It feels like this could have used around six months more in the oven, if only to balance characters and co-op. My friend and I played a few hours of co-op, and the game feels immensely unfair. Even by the third level, enemy damage spikes drastically; having green or better items doesn't really make much of a difference after a certain point.
-Base player movement is too slow.
-Artificer is one of, if not the worst, characters in the game. Her flame chakrams lack enough damage to be worth using. I feel that an improvement to them would be to add a trailing flame behind each chakram throw, that way you do not have to time each throw perfectly so that it hits an enemy dead-on, and flame damage can be more easily stacked.
-Drones deal too little damage and die way too quickly to be worth using a majority of the time.
-Bustling Fungus needs a buff, badly. I know I'm not the only one that thinks this. Its ability needs to activate when you are standing still and attacking, as it does so in RoR2. You're running around and dodging attacks too much on later levels to make it viable to stand around for a few seconds to get healed.
-Enemies get huge buffs at level 3, at the earliest. That's insane. Sometimes you've barely gathered any good items because of poor RNG and you end up getting steamrolled pretty quickly.
-PLEASE get rid of the ball-shaped bouncing enemies that show up in the underground cavern level, or nerf them somehow. They're terrible to fight, and are more obnoxious than they are a true challenge.
-Traversing some levels, such as the aforementioned Underground Cavern, is a chore and not enjoyable. I feel that this would be well mitigated by buffing base player speed and putting more chests in each level to increase the player's chance of finding movement buffs and items overall.
-Chests are spread too thin and sometimes it feels as if the current level doesn't have any chests at all.

Pops off, just like RoR2. I personally have never played the original Risk of Rain, and I knew full well going in that switching from 3d to 2d would probably short circuit my brain a bit, but I still went for it and I'm glad I did. The 2d has really grown on me, and so too has the unique way that this game plays compared to the 3d sequel. The pixel art is phenomenal, I mean just gorgeous, and the little comparison in the credits of the sprite work from the original game to the remaster, cute as hell. The one "downside" I kinda have, though it's hardly super negative, is that, by comparison, this game feels a good bit harder than 2. Not really a big deal, but something I noticed while trying to get one of my friends into it is that this specific jump in difficulty seems to make the game just barely cross that line of "worth learning" for some people. Again, I love it, but I also have hundreds of hours in RoR2 that have built a very solid foundation for me to start with. I immediately have a great deal of, at the very least, baseline knowledge of certain fundamentals and mechanics. For someone like my friend, who has never played 2, or the original for that matter, the sheer amount of stuff that is immediately thrown at you, with little explanation, proved to be a bit overwhelming. You can still do your best and learn in the process, but for some people, dying every minute or so to an enemy you don't understand how to effectively fight can stunt most, if not all enjoyment of the experience. I feel 2 eased you into what it's all about a lot smoother than this game does, and for some people, that can make or break the whole thing. AGAIN THOUGH, not me. This shit is digital crack cocaine.

If you are coming from risk of rain 2, and never played the original game, sure, get it. If you've played the first game, and are expecting a remaster, don't be fooled. This is a re-skin of the first game, with some extra content such as characters and enemies. Most, if not all problems I had with the first game are completely present here, and you will have to slowly trudge through identical stages getting items which end up mostly being equipment items that do nothing for you.

Its more Risk of Rain. Fair warning, the learning curve and difficulty is higher than RoR2, and the amount of visual noise gets too much at times during chaotic moments. 

2D is a harder challenge, so it might not be for everyone.

If you liked the OG risk of rain you'll like this one. It combines some elements of RoR2 into the gameplay (can teleport as soon as you beat the boss and teleporter charges, items from RoR2, etc...). Providence trials are all really fun and offer an additional way to unlock character abilities. 10/10 would chance precipitation again.

An excellent quality of life remake to one of the best roguelikes in the past 20 years. Risk of Rain provides more than an adequate experience for those seeking extreme challenges, while simultaneously being accessible to pick up and play with even casual gamer friends. Multiplayer brings a lot to Risk of Rain, but is far from required.

The best possible way to do a remaster. want new content? hell yeah, it's got lots of that. don't want new content? you can disable whatever new content you don't want. that alone makes it a 9/10, even without making consideration for what new content is present, none of which feels out of place. reimaginations of soundtracks from the original game, masterful spritework for assets new and old, an entirely optional set of largely well-designed minigame trials. 10/10.
